issueDTO.title: Type Hints: Add type hints to tutorials, snippets and examples
issueDTO.description:
To improve code readability and be friendlier to [PEP 484](https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0484/), we should start adding type annotations to our code, probably starting from snippets, tutorials and examples.

Originally discussed here https://github.com/falconry/falcon/pull/1737#issuecomment-744064360
comments:
Hi :wave:,

Thanks for using Falcon. The large amount of time and effort needed to
maintain the project and develop new features is not sustainable without
the generous financial support of community members like you.

Please consider helping us secure the future of the Falcon framework with a
one-time or recurring donation.

Thank you for your support!
See also https://github.com/falconry/falcon/issues/1350, which strives after full typing support for the whole codebase.
@vytas7 I can start working on this
@bibekjoshi54 Awesome sauce! Go ahead.
That would be great!

Just to throw it out there: I think a [Protocol](https://peps.python.org/pep-0544/) would be a great fit for `resource` in :
https://github.com/falconry/falcon/blob/4910dd73ecd1b9c8cf6cae045b26ad432fa56128/falcon/routing/compiled.py#L150

Something like:

```py
from typing import Protocol

from falcon.request import Request
from falcon.response import Response

class Resource(Protocol):
    def on_get(self, request: Request, resp: Response)) -> None:
        ...

    def on_post(self, request: Request, resp: Response)) -> None:
        ...

    # and so on ...
```

Then the signature would become:
```py
 def add_route(self, uri_template: str, resource: Resource, suffix: str | None = None, compile: bool = False)
```

The only caveat is that implementor would have to provide **all** the methods
(although could easily just `...` those with no implementation)

... at least until [optional protocol members](https://peps.python.org/pep-0544/#support-optional-protocol-members) are supported, something I've also raised [here](https://discuss.python.org/t/an-actual-need-for-optional-protocol-members/44257) 🤞🏻

That's an option, but I'm not sure it would provide much in terms of help for a user, since once the `add_route` call happens the class is already defined.

Maybe it could be used a "TypingResource" that may be used by user as superclass, where each method is defined in a type_checking block (to avoid it being picked up by the router). This could be useful since ide can autocomplete the signature of methods when overloading one.

Something like
```py
class TypeCheckResource:
  """Superclass of a Resource for typing purposes"""
  if TYPE_CHECKING:
    def on_get(self, req: Request, resp: Response, **path_args: Any) -> None:
      """Handles the GET method"""
    ...
```

>  once the `add_route` call happens the class is already defined.

True, but in the current implementation if that class had say:
```py
class MyResource:
    def on_get(self, req: str, bad: int)

app.add_route(uri_template, MyResource())
```

Then it would still type check okay (and the IDE wouldn't complain), because there is currently no typing for `resource` in:
https://github.com/falconry/falcon/blob/4910dd73ecd1b9c8cf6cae045b26ad432fa56128/falcon/routing/compiled.py#L150

---

A super class (or even better an [ABC](https://docs.python.org/3/library/abc.html)) would work,
but it would require* everyone to explicitly to [`register`](https://docs.python.org/3/library/abc.html#abc.ABCMeta.register) (or subclass) `TypeCheckResource`.

\* assuming the goal would be to change the signature of `add_route` to ?????? , so that is type checked correctly.
```py
def add_route(self, uri_template: str, resource: TypeCheckResource,...
```

---

The nice thing about protocols is that we could add the `resource: Resource` type to `add_route` and no one would _have_* to change their code, except in the case that:
1. They already have type annotations in their resource class, and:
2. Those type annotations are incorrect.

Put another way: it would allow graceful adoption of typing, without forcing everyone to do it.

\* incidentally protocols do also allow for [explicitly declaring an implementation](https://peps.python.org/pep-0544/#explicitly-declaring-implementation) if someone wanted to verify the types of a resource class before they tried to use it in `add_route`.

... but that's all academic until/unless https://github.com/python/typing/issues/601 happens 😑
I'll try to help with it :)
I can work on this issue

@zodecky that sounds great!
Let's just check with Ond??ej V??zner, @VOndrej42 do you have any code left from the Sprint in Prague maybe?

Here's all the stubs I've collected, if it helps:
https://github.com/JEFuller/falcon-types

Thanks for sharing @davetapley :+1: 

On that note, could you test Falcon [`4.0.0b2`](https://pypi.org/project/falcon/4.0.0b2/) out of the box without any other additional hints or typeshed packages for Falcon, and see if it works with your app?
@vytas7 amazing, looks good, a few issues incoming, but regardless thanks for all the hard work 🙏🏻

issueDTO.title: Add configuration that allows dbbackup to read/write locally more easily.
issueDTO.description: Right now, when you run dbbackup, it pulls from settings.py and the config there tells it to read S3. To make it read from local instead, you need to update settings.py. This isn't ideal. It would be nice if we could set some kind of argument or pass an env var into the command to make it look for files locally instead. This should require just some logic in settings.py.
comments:
here's the code in question
https://github.com/nycmeshnet/meshdb/blob/main/src/meshdb/settings.py#L293-L298

django-dbbackup has a way to configure saving/loading to local files
https://django-dbbackup.readthedocs.io/en/stable/storage.html

So the ask is to add some kind of environment variable that will configure S3 if set one way, and local if set another
resolved with [this PR](https://github.com/nycmeshnet/meshdb/pull/959)

issueDTO.title: Treat `.pyc` imports as `typing.Any` when no stubs can be found
issueDTO.description:
When a project uses `.pyc` imports, the source may not exist. In that case, when there are no analyzable source or stubs available, we probably shouldn't return an error on imports that can't be resolved, since we can't do the usual trick of inferring type annotations from unannotated code. There is no decompiled code for us to use!

Instead, we should use this logic: when we see a `<file>.pyc` import, but no non-`pyc` candidate, we should automatically perform the work of `replace_import_with_any`.

We'll likely want to do that by updating the [`FindResult`](https://github.com/facebook/pyrefly/blob/fffb8477b0ce8d4cb4eff311db2589fa3564c90d/pyrefly/lib/module/finder.rs#L33) to add a new variant for `.pyc` results, which when searching are lower precedence than `.pyi`, but higher than `NamespacePackages`.

We should also update the [configuration documentation](https://github.com/facebook/pyrefly/blob/fffb8477b0ce8d4cb4eff311db2589fa3564c90d/website/docs/configuration.mdx?plain=1#L265) to mention that we do this, since this behavior might be unexpected.

---

You can test this yourself with the following: 
1. `uv venv venv && source venv/bin/activate && pip install requests && cd $(python3 -c "import site; print(site.gesitepackages()[0])")/requests`
    - Note: this attempts to cd into the site directory that `requests` was installed into. If it was the wrong site package directory, then inspect other `site.getsitepackages()` directories to find the `requests` directory.
2. `python3 -m compileall *`
    - Note: you can also have the same effect as this by passing in `--compile` to `pip install requests`
4. `rm *.py && mv __pycache__/* . && rm -rf __pycache__`
5. `python3 -c 'import os; [os.rename(file, ".".join([part for part in file.split(".") if "cpython" not in part])) for file in os.listdir()]'`

The above should set up requests to look like a compiled library.
comments: Thanks for outlining the issue. I'm currently working on an internal fix to handle .pyc imports when no stubs are available. I'll keep you updated on the progress and ensure our tests and configuration docs reflect this new preferred behavior.

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it is assigned, but has not had recent activity for more than 2 weeks.

If you are still working on this issue, please add a comment to keep it active. Otherwise, please unassign yourself and allow someone else to take over.

Thank you for your contributions!

issueDTO.title: Could you register this package in Homebrew, the macOS/Linux package manager?
issueDTO.description: That will be extremely helpful for us to install. Thank you!
comments:
It usually makes the most sense to pip/uv install so each project can have the pyrefly version pinned in a .venv (pyrefly version changes can change typecheck results which change the codebase). But for people who want a global installation, brew would be great!

for reference, [here](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/pull/412863) a community contribution adding pyrefly to nix's package manager

Yes. I do want a global installation of `pyrefly` since I don't want to install it multiple times for each project. I could help with registering a Homebrew formula, but the thing is I don't know what are its dependencies? `rust`? Sorry I'm not that familiar with how to build Rust projects.

Here's a simple Rust formula on Homebrew you can use for example: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/a6c3edea18b10f489117532cacfa8a87285d8b60/Formula/f/ferron.rb

I suggest making a [Homebrew Tap](https://docs.brew.sh/Taps) repository and refer to this documentation for guidance: https://docs.brew.sh/Formula-Cookbook

Also, this documentation explains how to get the SHA256 hashes for the `bottle` block: https://docs.brew.sh/Bottles

[In the Formula docs they say](https://docs.brew.sh/Formula-Cookbook#grab-the-url) this command makes a local tap and opens it in your `$EDITOR`:
```sh
brew create "https://github.com/facebook/pyrefly/archive/refs/tags/0.18.0.tar.gz"
```
(the URL is from https://github.com/facebook/pyrefly/tags)

Alternatively, instead of installing it like a Rust project, you can try installing it like a Python project a here: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/blob/6497d2c6f7bfbfe920617af90c7e2dc1f2e93507/Formula/a/archey4.rb

Not sure how well it will work though. Building from Rust source is probably the most certain way.

Maybe something like this:
```rb
class Pyrefly < Formula
  desc "Fast type checker and IDE for Python"
  homepage "https://pyrefly.org/"
  url "https://github.com/facebook/pyrefly/archive/refs/tags/0.18.0.tar.gz"
  sha256 "fcc7529c577d6d8e9fcc53387b2af5c7252e41baba434a591b0c6dc4a35cc51c"
  license "MIT"
  head "https://github.com/facebook/pyrefly.git"

  depends_on "rust" => :build

  def install
    system "cargo", "install", *std_cargo_args(path: "pyrefly")
  end

  test do
    # This is a bad test. I'm not sure how to test pyrefly properly.
    assert_equal "pyrefly 0.18.0", shell_output("#{bin}/pyrefly -V").strip
  end
end
```
PS: I have not tested this. It may need some/many modifications.

@singularitti thanks for looking into this! I've assigned this issue to you for now, since you have the open PR on Homebrew's repository. Let us know if you want help, don't want to work on it anymore, or if you finish it!

Hi @connernilsen, thanks! That would be great! I am currently having one trouble is that `pyrefly` relies the [nightly build of `rust`](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/225813/files#diff-de3bcfe5c83d666536305b2a8f677332e9a2a7bbc09b5c32a69e4023f025c3dcR16) and Homebrew maintainers don't like it (See [this thread](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/225813#discussion_r2131455369)). Is it necessary to use the nightly build or can I find a workaround?

The way I did it in `nixpkgs` is using `RUSTC_BOOTSTRAP=1`, but I have little knowledge of Rust so I don't know if what it is eligible for Homebrew. See this thread: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/225813#discussion_r2131492639

If it doesn't do what they're concerned about, then it is probably the way to go.

I'm pretty sure we need to use the nighty version (or `RUSTC_BOOTSTRAP` if that works too), but I don't think I know enough about Rust right now to make a good argument for it. @ndmitchell, why are we using a nightly Rust version? Maybe we can craft an argument for it here and add it to the [discussion on the Homebrew issue](https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew-core/pull/225813#discussion_r2131455369).

The ultimate solution is to stop using Rust nightly, which we are tracking at #374 - it's likely to take a few more months to get there.

Until then, a stable release with `RUSTC_BOOTSTRAP=1` should work fine. The rule is that stable Rust compilers can't use `feature` declarations (e.g. features who haven't been fully stabilized), but nightlies and with the environment variable set can do so.

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it is assigned, but has not had recent activity for more than 2 weeks.

If you are still working on this issue, please add a comment to keep it active. Otherwise, please unassign yourself and allow someone else to take over.

Thank you for your contributions!

issueDTO.title: IP150+ module do support SWAN disable - only local LAN network
issueDTO.description:
<!-- Provide a general summary of the feature request in the *Title* above -->
Hi just want to let you know, that there are special code that you can enter durring the IP 150+ module configuraiton, which allows you to use the module in LAN mode, without forcing or using SWAN servers. 
In that mode, you are loosing ability to control the panel trough a WEB interface of the IP150+ module itself, but still you can manage the panel trough Paradox Gold app (and also through babyware and reprogramming)
It is working perfectly fine with HAAS as well. (Currently running on EVO192 with 6.5 - not encrypted FW)
Now upgrade request, no additional configuration of 150+ needed

Copying the screenshot of it
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228909855-4b88928e-ae2a-49fe-9557-d3ce687094db.png)

So this is a dedicated firmware v5.06.016 for ip150+ with support with all the new panels and firmware.

The only thing you should do is to enter "special firmware access code "IP150PCN" durring the upgrade process of IP150+.
It is possible from inField and Paradox Gold App.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228911586-9e00432f-bc9f-4516-9c43-352ce4164777.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228911614-f29d0b41-9496-4bb0-aeb4-e5c5f15ee27a.png)

in the Paradox Gold App is available in installer section
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/106034385/228911768-7d9caee5-71bf-4e05-be51-4bc39157112e.png)

Statement from paradox!
Use the "IP150PCN" beta key to downgrade the module to v.5.06.016 for closed network operation.
v5.06.016 has a web interface for network setup. When SWAN polling is disabled, there is no trouble for network connection in closed networks.

## Feature description
<!-- Describe the feature -->

comments:
# :wave: Important: PLEASE READ :wave:

This issue has been labeled as a **good first issue** and is available for anyone to work on.

If this is your first time contributing to an open source project, some aspects of the development process may seem unusual, arcane, or some combination of both.

1.  **You cannot "claim" issues.** People new to open source often want to "claim" or be assigned an issue before beginning work. The typical rationale is that people want to avoid wasted work in the event that someone else ends up working the issue. However, this practice is not effective in open source, as it often leads to "issue squatting", in which an individual asks to be assigned, is granted their request, and then never ends up working on the issue. Accordingly, you are encouraged to communicate your intent to address this issue, ideally by providing a rough outline as to how you plan to address the issue or asking clarifying questions, but, at the end of the day, we will take running code and rough consensus in order to move forward quickly.
2.  **We have a very high bar for contributions.** We have very high standards for contributions and expect all contributions???whether new features, tests, or documentation???to be rigorous, thorough, and complete. Once a pull request is merged into stdlib, that contribution immediately becomes the collective responsibility of all maintainers of stdlib. When we merge code into stdlib, we are saying that we, the maintainers, commit to reviewing subsequent changes and making bugfixes to the code. Hence, in order to ensure future maintainability, this naturally leads to a higher standard of contribution.

Before working on this issue and opening a pull request, please read the project's [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CONTRIBUTING.md). These guidelines and the associated [development guide](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/docs/contributing/development.md) provide important information, including links to stdlib's [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/blob/develop/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md), license policy, and steps for setting up your local development environment.

To reiterate, we **strongly** encourage you to refer to our contributing guides **before** beginning work on this issue. Failure to follow our guidelines significantly decreases the likelihood that you'll successfully contribute to stdlib and may result in automatic closure of a pull request without review.

Setting up your local development environment is a critical first step, as doing so ensures that automated development processes for linting, license verification, and unit testing can run prior to authoring commits and pushing changes. If you would prefer to avoid manual setup, we provide pre-configured [development containers](https://github.com/stdlib-js/stdlib/tree/develop/.devcontainer) for use locally or in GitHub Codespaces.

We place a high value on consistency throughout the stdlib codebase. We encourage you to closely examine other packages in stdlib and attempt to emulate the practices and conventions found therein.

-   If you are attempting to contribute a new package, sometimes the best approach is to simply copy the contents of an existing package and then modify the minimum amount necessary to implement the feature (e.g., changing descriptions, parameter names, and implementation).
-   If you are contributing tests, find a package implementing a similar feature and emulate the tests of that package.
-   If you are updating documentation, examine several similar packages and emulate the content, style, and prose of those packages.

In short, the more effort you put in to ensure that your contribution looks and feels like stdlib???including variables names, bracket spacing, line breaks, etc???the more likely that your contribution will be reviewed and ultimately accepted. We encourage you to closely study the codebase **before** beginning work on this issue.

:sparkles: Thank you again for your interest in stdlib, and we look forward to reviewing your future contributions. :sparkles:

issueDTO.title: Readfile should accept filenames with `-` and return file content along with corrected filename.
issueDTO.description:
The read_file tool should accept filenames with `-` and return file content along with corrected filename. 

More clearly read_file normally fails if the file isn't found...

but when it's a simple problem where the filename is `src/example/core-stuff.clj` when it should be `src/example/core_stuff.clj` we should fix it but set a flag to add a notice to the output that we the original filename is wrong and we are providing the corrected result instead...

The collapsed view output shows how to add extra messaging along with file contents
comments:
how do you trigger read_file like this? 

i have a fork of `clojure-mcp` with an nrepl running against it.  doing a `tail -F ~/Library/Logs/Claude/mcp-server-clojure-mcp:7888.log`.  start claude desktop, + the PROJECT_SUMMARY.md, and ask a question about files with - dashes instead of _, even ones that aren't in the summary.  it still gets the correct files right away.

issueDTO.title: [Bug]: Issue with IllegalStateException in `STORAGE_WRITE_API` method in `BigQueryIO`
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

I am running a Beam pipeline in Google Dataflow (Beam SDK version `2.56.0`) that reads messages from Pub/Sub and writes data to a BigQuery table using the STORAGE_WRITE_API method. 
This is the BigQueryIO configuration I'm using:
```
BigQueryIO.write<KV<String, TableRow>>().to(
                BigQueryDestination(...)
            )
                .withFormatFunction { it.value } // Get TableRow
                .withCreateDisposition(BigQueryIO.Write.CreateDisposition.CREATE_IF_NEEDED)
                .withWriteDisposition(BigQueryIO.Write.WriteDisposition.WRITE_APPEND)
                .withFailedInsertRetryPolicy(InsertRetryPolicy.retryTransientErrors())
                .withMethod(BigQueryIO.Write.Method.STORAGE_WRITE_API)
                .withTriggeringFrequency(Duration.standardMinutes(5))
                .withAutoSharding()
                .ignoreUnknownValues()
```

comments: Is the error transient?

> Is the error transient?
No, the error is not transient
It occurs frequently in the pipeline logs
![aaaa](https://github.com/apache/beam/assets/133836482/a0675348-84ee-49fa-aedf-d7501f6fe8c0)

Since this is a streaming job, is the job often stuck? 
I also suggest you open a GCP support ticket (https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/docs/support/getting-support). 
I have seen some issues similar to this but they are often caused by some Java package mismatches.

The trackstace points to here: https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/8c6e1a4654bced7bf732e1a46092908580da561b/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/BigQueryServicesImpl.java#L1459

indicates the client is already closed when one trying to write records via "StorageApiWritesShardedRecords".

"closed" could only be true when StreamAppendClient.close is called.

Sounds like some racing condition happened there.

Note that "WritesShardedRecords" is used to write spilled records that not handled by "WritesUnShardedRecords" and is a less execised code.

In any case, open a support ticket so cloud support could inspect your job ID. I see a public bug opened for https://b.corp.google.com/issues/345352979 this is not a usual process

> The trackstace points to here:
> 
> https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/8c6e1a4654bced7bf732e1a46092908580da561b/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/BigQueryServicesImpl.java#L1459
> 
> indicates the client is already closed when one trying to write records via "StorageApiWritesShardedRecords".
>

> 
> Sounds like some racing condition happened there.
> 
> Note that "WritesShardedRecords" is used to write spilled records that not handled by "WritesUnShardedRecords" and is a less execised code.
> 
> In any case, open a support ticket so cloud support could inspect your job ID. I see a public bug opened for https://b.corp.google.com/issues/345352979 this is not a usual process

I created a GCP support ticket.

There are two places closing the client:

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWriteUnshardedRecords.java#L392

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java#L517

Apparent racing condition most likely client already marked closed here, then in 

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java#L600

it tries to use the client and fails precondition.

It's hard to locate where the client get closed (async and lambda programming code style). Basically, there is a APPEND_CLIENTS cache:

https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/2ddfcfb1c18020d0c01c7ebfe5d898a5b8a303b6/sdks/java/io/google-cloud-platform/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/gcp/bigquery/StorageApiWritesShardedRecords.java#L181

removal of cache item will trigger `appendClientInfo.close` which calls `getCloseAppendClient().accept(client)` that is the code above.

Then what happens is the cache entry contains the client get invalidated before it's going to be used again.

I get the same error  with `apache-beam 2.65.0`. I also read from PubSub and write to BigQuery. I use the Python SDK (though behind the curtains the PubSub and BigQuery connectors just call the java implementations).

We're still seeing this with the latest apache-beam 2.66.0 release using the `STORAGE_WRITE_API` method with the python sdk and the GCP dataflow runner. The error log from the dataflow workers are below:

@jbandoro possible to let us know how to reproduce this?

Similar to the OP but with the python sdk, we're reading messages from a Pub/Sub subscription (with `beam.io.gcp.pubsub.ReadFromPubSub`), parsing the records and then writing to BigQuery with:

```python
        parsed_messages | "Write to BigQuery" >> beam.io.WriteToBigQuery(
            table=FULL_TABLE_ID,
            schema=TABLE_SCHEMA,
            write_disposition=beam.io.BigQueryDisposition.WRITE_APPEND,
            method=beam.io.WriteToBigQuery.Method.STORAGE_WRITE_API,
            with_auto_sharding=True,
        )
```

Using `apache-beam==2.66.0` with the DataflowRunner on a streaming pipeline with the `streaming_mode_at_least_once` mode. We're using a custom dataflow image following the instructions in the [docs](https://cloud.google.com/dataflow/docs/guides/build-container-image). 

From my testing setting `with_auto_sharding` to False still resulted in the the errors I posted in the comment above. One arg for `WriteToBigQuery` that seemed to reduce the frequency of the errors was to set `triggering_frequency` to a value above 5 seconds. I also set some custom metric counters and it doesn't appear that we're loosing any data as the retries by the workers are working and all the streaming data is landing in the BigQuery sink.

Let me know if there's anything else that would be helpful or steps I can take, thanks!

repository.description: Apache Beam is a unified programming model for Batch and Streaming data processing.

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to resolve the IllegalStateException error in the pipeline logs when running a Beam pipeline in Google Dataflow that reads messages from Pub/Sub and writes data to a BigQuery table using the STORAGE_WRITE_API method.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue is related to the STORAGE_WRITE_API method and the Beam SDK version 2.56.0. The error is not transient and occurs frequently in the pipeline logs.
summary.attemptedFixes: The issue is not fixed yet, but a support ticket has been opened to investigate the issue further. Setting with_auto_sharding to False did not resolve the issue. Setting triggering_frequency to a value above 5 seconds seemed to reduce the frequency of the errors.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about an IllegalStateException error in the pipeline logs when running a Beam pipeline in Google Dataflow (Beam SDK version 2.56.0) that reads messages from Pub/Sub and writes data to a BigQuery table using the STORAGE_WRITE_API method. The error is not transient and occurs frequently in the pipeline logs. The job is not stuck and is running normally, but the error logs are quite annoying. The issue is related to a racing condition in the client closure, and a support ticket has been opened. The error is also reproduced with apache-beam 2.65.0 and 2.66.0.

Hence, we need to review and update this page. Ideally, we should have this doc page pull code from `.cpp`/`CMakeLists.txt` files that are validated by the CI.

issueDTO.title: Daily Login Rewards System
issueDTO.description:
This standalone DailyRewardModule implements a daily check-in system that rewards users for logging in each day. It includes support for streak tracking and cooldown enforcement to ensure users can only claim rewards once per day. This feature is designed to boost user retention and daily engagement.

**Tasks:**

* [ ] Create `DailyRewardLog` entity to track user check-ins and streaks
* [ ] Implement logic for streak counting and cooldown (24-hour restriction)
* [ ] Create `POST /rewards/daily-checkin` endpoint to claim the reward and return current streak info

```rust
#[cfg_attr(feature = "serde", derive(serde::Serialize, serde::Deserialize))]

```

matches the non standard `eth_getAccountInfo` endpoint response:

https://github.com/alloy-rs/alloy/blob/c04ef82f3a63c97cb3332a78b3c18dca47966ad3/crates/rpc-types-eth/src/account.rs#L9-L21

```
   let (nonce, balance, code) = tokio::join!(nonce, balance, code,);
```

issueDTO.title: API documentation incorrectly states that resizePolicy can be set to ephemeral containers
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

![???????????? 2024-10-27 172423](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/67362294-40c0-4af6-a4e9-40b06f9ec9e8)
Based on the concept of `resizePolicy`, it is expected behavior that `resizePolicy` cannot be assigned to ephemeral containers, as they do not support resource requests or limits.

However, in the Kubernetes v1.31 API documentation, there is no clear indication that the `resizePolicy` option is disallowed for ephemeral containers, which may lead to confusion for users.
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c480ec78-4c3d-4190-8339-e10e03bed9ca)
![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/10b178ba-299b-4e06-a9dc-aa139851cbb6)

### `pkg/apis/core/validation/validation_test.go`
```go
func TestValidateEphemeralContainers(t *testing.T) {
...
...
...
	{
			"Container uses disallowed field: ResizePolicy",
			line(),
			[]core.EphemeralContainer{{
				EphemeralContainerCommon: core.EphemeralContainerCommon{
					Name:                     "resources-resize-policy",
					Image:                    "image",
					ImagePullPolicy:          "IfNotPresent",
					TerminationMessagePolicy: "File",
					ResizePolicy: []core.ContainerResizePolicy{
						{ResourceName: "cpu", RestartPolicy: "NotRequired"},
					},
				},
			}},
			field.ErrorList{{Type: field.ErrorTypeForbidden, Field: "ephemeralContainers[0].resizePolicy"}},
		}
	...
	...
	...
```
As shown in the code above, it is explicitly stated that `resizePolicy` cannot be assigned to ephemeral containers.
This restriction is not reflected in the API documentation, potentially leading users to believe they can apply `resizePolicy` to ephemeral containers. Including this limitation in the documentation would improve clarity and enhance the user experience.

### What did you expect to happen?

The Kubernetes v1.31 API documentation should clearly state that `resizePolicy` cannot be assigned to ephemeral containers, as they do not support resource requests or limits. This clarification would prevent users from mistakenly assuming that `resizePolicy` can be applied to ephemeral containers and help avoid configuration errors.

### How can we reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)?

1. Go to the Kubernetes v1.31 API documentation.
2. [Navigate to the section discussing `resizePolicy` for containers.](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/v1.31/#containerresizepolicy-v1-core)
3. [Review the documentation regarding ephemeral containers.](https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/generated/kubernetes-api/v1.31/#ephemeralcontainer-v1-core)
4. Observe that there is no mention or clarification that `resizePolicy` cannot be applied to ephemeral containers, leading to potential misunderstandings.

### Anything else we need to know?

_No response_

### Kubernetes version

<details>

```console
$ kubectl version
Client Version: v1.31.1
Kustomize Version: v5.4.2
Server Version: v1.31.1

```

</details>


### Cloud provider

<details>
On-Premises
</details>

### OS version

<details>

```console
# On Linux:
$ cat /etc/os-release
RETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 22.04.4 LTS"
NAME="Ubuntu"
VERSION_ID="22.04"
VERSION="22.04.4 LTS (Jammy Jellyfish)"
VERSION_CODENAME=jammy
ID=ubuntu
ID_LIKE=debian
HOME_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/"
SUPPORT_URL="https://help.ubuntu.com/"
BUG_REPORT_URL="https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/"
PRIVACY_POLICY_URL="https://www.ubuntu.com/legal/terms-and-policies/privacy-policy"
UBUNTU_CODENAME=jammy

$ uname -a
Linux masternode-virtual-machine 6.8.0-47-generic #47~22.04.1-Ubuntu SMP PREEMPT_DYNAMIC Wed Oct  2 16:16:55 UTC 2 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux

```

</details>


### Install tools

<details>
kubeadm
</details>


### Container runtime (CRI) and version (if applicable)

<details>
containerd
</details>


### Related plugins (CNI, CSI, ...) and versions (if applicable)

issueDTO.title: Add shortcut for delete session in webui
issueDTO.description:
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c8935aa7-f3a6-4c15-82a1-fb01882395a7)

---
The Saiki WebUI allows users to delete sessions through the Sessions Panel (???J), but lacks a keyboard shortcut for this common action, which disrupts workflow.

  ## Current State
  - Sessions are managed through the SessionPanel component
  - Deletion is available via trash icon buttons with confirmation dialogs
  - The old "Reset Conversation" button mentioned in previous steps has been removed
  - Current shortcuts: ???J (sessions), ???K (tools), ???L (playground), ??????E (export), ???/ (shortcuts)

  ## Proposed Solution
  Add **??? + Backspace** keyboard shortcut to delete the current session, following the same confirmation flow as the
  existing delete buttons.

  ## Implementation Steps

  ### 1. Add keyboard shortcut handler in `ChatApp.tsx`:
  ```tsx
  // In the existing handleKeyDown function
  if ((e.metaKey || e.ctrlKey) && e.key === 'Backspace') {
    e.preventDefault();
    if (currentSessionId && !isWelcomeState) {
      // Trigger same deletion flow as SessionPanel delete button
      // Show confirmation dialog for sessions with messages
    }
  }
```
  2. Update shortcuts modal in ChatApp.tsx:

```tsx
  // Add to existing shortcuts array
  { key: isMac ? '??????' : 'Ctrl+???', desc: 'Delete current session' }
```
  3. Handle deletion logic:

  - Use existing deleteSession function from ChatContext
  - Implement same confirmation dialog as SessionPanel
  - Return to welcome state after deletion

  Files to modify

  - src/app/webui/components/ChatApp.tsx (keyboard handler + shortcuts modal)
  - Test the functionality matches existing delete behavior

  UX Considerations

  - Should follow same confirmation flow as existing delete buttons
  - Shortcut only active when there's a current session (not in welcome state)
  - Clear feedback when deletion completes

  This improves workflow by allowing quick session deletion without opening the sessions panel.

## Testing Steps

refer `src/app/webui/README.md` for steps to set up the webUI locally for testing

issueDTO.title: Semantics of 'default' resource names in openchoreo.dev api group
issueDTO.description:
### Description

#### Organization `default`
This default organization will be mapped to the `default` K8s namespace of the control plane cluster. Most OpenChoreo CRs are part of an organization. Still, if the organization field is not present in the CR, then we assume that all such resources are part of the `default` organization. 

#### Project `default`
A component must always be associated with a project; however, if you omit the project name in the Component CR, it will be added to the default project.

#### DeploymentPipeline `default`
A project should always be associated with a DeploymentPipeline, but if this field is not present in the Project CR, it is assumed to be associated with the default pipeline. 

#### DataPlane `default`
All environments (dev, staging, prod) refer to the `default` DataPlane by default. When you install the control plane and the data plane in the same cluster, the default data plane points to the same K8s cluster. 

You can optionally use a different Kubernetes (K8s) cluster and refer to it in your default data plane. 

#### BuildPlane `default`
We introduced the BuildPlane concept in https://github.com/openchoreo/openchoreo/issues/217#issuecomment-2917158174.  We create a `default` build plane that points to the same K8s cluster as the default data plane by default.
comments: @chalindukodikara @Mirage20, please note!

issueDTO.title: `ValueError` raised by `FeatureUnion._set_output` with `FunctionTransform` that outputs a pandas `Series` in scikit-learn version 1.6
issueDTO.description:
### Describe the bug

Hello,

I'm currently working with scikit-learn version 1.6, and I encountered a regression that wasn't present in version 1.4.

The following minimal code computes two features ??? the cumulative mean of age and weight grouped by id. Each transformation function returns a pandas.Series:



When I run this code with scikit-learn 1.6, I get the following error:

After investigation, I found that the issue occurs because each transformer returns a Series, not a DataFrame. If I update the functions to return DataFrame objects instead, the error disappears.

Interestingly, in scikit-learn 1.4, the same code works correctly even when the functions return Series.


Do you have any explanation for why this changed between version 1.4 and 1.6 ?

Thanks in advance for your help!

### Steps/Code to Reproduce


```python
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.pipeline import FunctionTransformer, FeatureUnion
import numpy as np

def compute_cumulative_mean_age(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.Series:
    return (
        df["age"]
        .astype(float)
        .groupby(df["id"])
        .expanding()
        .mean()
        .droplevel(level="id")
        .reindex(df.index)
        .rename("cumulative_mean_age")
    )

def compute_cumulative_mean_weight(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.Series:
    return (
        df["poids"]
        .astype(float)
        .groupby(df["id"])
        .expanding()
        .mean()
        .droplevel(level="id")
        .reindex(df.index)
        .rename("cumulative_mean_weight")
    )

def compute_features(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    feature_union = FeatureUnion(
        [
            ("cumulative_mean_age", FunctionTransformer(compute_cumulative_mean_age)),
            ("cumulative_mean_weight", FunctionTransformer(compute_cumulative_mean_weight))
        ]
    ).set_output(transform="pandas")

    return feature_union.fit_transform(X=df).astype(float)

def transform(df: pd.DataFrame) -> pd.DataFrame:
    return compute_features(df)

if __name__ == "__main__":
    np.random.seed(42)
    df = pd.DataFrame({
        'id': [1, 2, 3, 1, 4, 5, 6, 6, 7, 8],
        'age': np.random.randint(18, 70, size=10),
        'poids': np.random.randint(50, 100, size=10)
    })

    print(transform(df))
```

### Expected Results

```pytb
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\tmp.py", line 73, in <module>
    print(transform(df=df))
          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\tmp.py", line 55, in transform
    return compute_features(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\tmp.py", line 45, in compute_features
    .fit_transform(
     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\.venv\Lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\_set_output.py", line 332, in wrapped
    return _wrap_data_with_container(method, data_to_wrap, X, self)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\.venv\Lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\_set_output.py", line 307, in _wrap_data_with_container
    return adapter.create_container(
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\.venv\Lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\_set_output.py", line 135, in create_container
    X_output = _create_pandas_dataframe_from_non_pandas_container(
               ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\.venv\Lib\site-packages\sklearn\utils\fixes.py", line 428, in _create_pandas_dataframe_from_non_pandas_container
    return pd.DataFrame(X, index=index, copy=copy)
           ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\.venv\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\frame.py", line 722, in __init__
    mgr = ndarray_to_mgr(
          ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\.venv\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\internals\construction.py", line 349, in ndarray_to_mgr
    _check_values_indices_shape_match(values, index, columns)
  File "C:\Users\XXX\PycharmProjects\fraude_detection_pec_audio\.venv\Lib\site-packages\pandas\core\internals\construction.py", line 420, in _check_values_indices_shape_match
    raise ValueError(f"Shape of passed values is {passed}, indices imply {implied}")
ValueError: Shape of passed values is (20, 1), indices imply (10, 1)
```

### Actual Results

```pytb
    raise ValueError(f"Shape of passed values is {passed}, indices imply {implied}")
ValueError: Shape of passed values is (20, 1), indices imply (10, 1)
```

### Versions

```shell
sklearn: 1.6.0
numpy: 1.26.4
pandas: 1.5.3
```
comments:
I would argue that the previous beahviour worked by chance but it was a bug. Scikit-learn transformers API expect to return an array of shape `(n_samples, n_features)`. Having a single dimension is really ambiguous because we cannot guess if it is a single sample or a single feature. For instance, if you use `set_output(transform="default")`, then you will get an array of shape `(20,)` where I would argue that the `FeatureUnion` failed.

So here, I think that the fact that we raise an error is actually fine. The error message is a bit tricky thought. The fact it does not raise with `set_output(transform="default")` is actually annoying I think.

So one way would be to validate the output of `FunctionTransformer` being sure it should be 2-D. However, we sometime want this transformer to be lenient so I wonder if the behaviour should be driven by a parameter, similarly to the `validate` parameter but for the output.

@jeremiedbb @ogrisel do you have any thoughts regarding if `FunctionTransformer` should be permissive regarding the shape of the output or if we should strictly follow the API of other transformers.

I'm thinking that we usually want this transformer to be permissive on the input side.

Note that the mentioned code already raises 2 informative warnings before raising the final exception:

```python
/Users/ogrisel/code/scikit-learn/sklearn/preprocessing/_function_transformer.py:311: UserWarning: When `set_output` is configured to be 'pandas', `func` should return a pandas DataFrame to follow the `set_output` API  or `feature_names_out` should be defined.
  warnings.warn(warn_msg.format("pandas"))
/Users/ogrisel/code/scikit-learn/sklearn/preprocessing/_function_transformer.py:311: UserWarning: When `set_output` is configured to be 'pandas', `func` should return a pandas DataFrame to follow the `set_output` API  or `feature_names_out` should be defined.
  warnings.warn(warn_msg.format("pandas"))
```

The function transformer should not return a pandas series but a pandas dataframe.

Maybe we could change this to accept series and automatically wrap them as dataframes because there is no ambiguity in this particular case.

If not, I agree that we should at least improve the error message.

Let me try to simplify the reproducer to make it minimal.

Here is a minimal reproducer:

```python
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.preprocessing import FunctionTransformer
from sklearn.pipeline import FeatureUnion


data = pd.DataFrame(dict(a=range(3), b=range(3)))
FeatureUnion(
    [
        ("a", FunctionTransformer(lambda df: df["a"])),
        ("b", FunctionTransformer(lambda df: df["b"])),  # exception not raised if you remove this line.
    ]
).set_output(transform="pandas").fit_transform(data)
```

Note that the `FeatureUnion` requires 2 series, otherwise there are no exceptions, only the warnings.

Actually, here is the real bug in my opinion: if you remove the `.set_output("pandas")` from the above snippet, the code works without failing or raising warnings but outputs meaningless results:

```python
import pandas as pd
from sklearn.preprocessing import FunctionTransformer
from sklearn.pipeline import FeatureUnion


data = pd.DataFrame(dict(a=range(3), b=range(3)))
FeatureUnion(
    [
        ("a", FunctionTransformer(lambda df: df["a"])),
        ("b", FunctionTransformer(lambda df: df["b"])),
    ]
).fit_transform(data)
```
```
array([0, 1, 2, 0, 1, 2])
```

Instead, `FeatureUnion` should raise an explicit error message to make it explicit that some transformers output 1d data-structures instead of the expected 2d.

I think the `FeatureUnion._hstack` method should be changed to raise an informative error message if some elements in `Xs` are not 2D data-structures. We should also check that their `.shape[0]` match the expected number of samples measured on the `X` parameter passed to `FeatureUnion.transform` or `FeatureUnion.fit_transform`.

EDIT: the error message of the exception should mention the name of the transformer that generated invalid output shapes along with the observed shape and the expected number of data points.
hello i am Ahsan , i am new to open source , i would like to contribute .
/take

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to understand why the `FeatureUnion` transformer in scikit-learn version 1.6 raises a `ValueError` when the output of a `FunctionTransformer` is a pandas `Series` instead of a DataFrame, and to find a solution to this problem.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The `FunctionTransformer` output should be a pandas DataFrame, not a Series. The `FeatureUnion` should raise an informative error message if some elements in `Xs` are not 2D data-structures.
summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests that the `FeatureUnion` should be permissive regarding the shape of the output, similar to the `validate` parameter. They also propose to validate the output of `FunctionTransformer` to ensure it should be 2-D. Additionally, they mention that the error message should be improved.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is about the `FeatureUnion` transformer in scikit-learn version 1.6, which raises a `ValueError` when the output of a `FunctionTransformer` is a pandas `Series` instead of a DataFrame. This change in behavior is observed between version 1.4 and 1.6.

issueDTO.title: 📎 Improve parsing and deserialisation of `package.json`
issueDTO.description:
### Description

The parsing and deserialisation of the `package.json` is very slow, we should look into it.

My gut tells me that most of the time is spent by the `node-semver` crate when we parse the version range of each dependency. 

We could **not** parse that information during the deserialization, and parse it only when needed.

@ematipico is there a test that I can run and measure the slowness please? else I am browsing the code and will try to find one, but would be faster if you give me a tip :-)

There's already a benchmark https://github.com/biomejs/biome/blob/main/crates/biome_package/benches/package_json.rs

Position yourself inside `biome_package` and run `cargo bench package_json` 


Here the codspeed benchmark: https://codspeed.io/biomejs/biome/benchmarks/crates/biome_package/benches/package_json.rs::package_json::bench_package_json::package_json::deserialize_from_json_str%5Bpackage.json%5D?runnerMode=Instrumentation

I don't understand the retry procedure (I should have a look to the code):
Polling in done every 30s (in my case)
polling is done at 12:18:48 / next polling should be performed at 12:19:18 (30s later)
Exception rose at 12:19:16 (before next polling)
Trace shows that we are already in retry procedure (exceptions.SaicApiRetryException) after some previous failure (not displayed)
What should be the delay between retries and number of retries ?

In this case, time between working/exception was 28s : it means we cannot cope with server unavailability longer than few seconds ?
if its any consolation its got worse for me too, i've got an automation that forces refresh when unavailable but isn't working reliably, it does seem to be worse if im plugged in.

> if its any consolation its got worse for me too, i've got an automation that forces refresh when unavailable but isn't working reliably, it does seem to be worse if im plugged in.

I tried the same automation setup to no avail. The frequent unavailability makes the setup near to unusable at times. Before it ran quite reliably for a long time, so I am too uncertain if this might have been some change in API policy on the SAIC side or some regression in an update.

Hi @nanomad, I had a look to the code:

In __execute_api_call (base.py #202)
we send are calling the API -> self.__api_client.send(req)
and receiving/analyzing the response -> self.__deserialize(req, response, out_type, allow_null_body)

in __deserialize (base.py #286)
when receiving a return_code = 4 (The remote control instruction failed, please try again later), we are raising SaicApiRetryException

But this exception does not seems to trigger any retry mechanism.

Raising this exception immediately cause the HA device to go to unavailable state (at the exact same second) :

2025-07-03 **13:37:53**,849 [ERROR]: handle_vehicle loop failed during SAIC API call - handlers.vehicle
Traceback (most recent call last):


![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/99682215-58cb-4cbf-89d8-569e5c93c131)


[bf995ce7_saic_python_mqtt_gateway_2025-07-03T15-50-31.929Z.log](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21041495/bf995ce7_saic_python_mqtt_gateway_2025-07-03T15-50-31.929Z.log)

Uhm that's weird, there's a SaicApiRetryPolicy that should handle exactly that scenario. 

Let me write a test case and check

I noticed this that should handle this case:  
@tenacity.retry(
            stop=tenacity.stop_after_delay(30),
            wait=delay or tenacity.wait_fixed(self.__configuration.sms_delivery_delay),
            retry=SaicApiRetryPolicy(),
            after=saic_api_after_retry,
            reraise=True,
        )

But I don't know exactly on which criteria it should be triggered (timeout, no answer, exception ?)

Anyway, thanks for having a look on it.

issueDTO.title: RASTER.createRaster() takes but does not process kwargs
issueDTO.description:
RASTER.createRaster() allows **kwargs, but if I am not mistaken, the kwargs are not processed in the method itself. This creates the problem that false args can be passed which then disappear unnoticed with as kwargs, and not only directly to createRaster() but also to createRasterLike() where the matter is much more critically as this method essentially depends on relevant kwargs. Example: When you have a ```data``` array with floats between 0.5 and 1.5 and save it as such:
```python
gk.raster.createRasterLike(
    source="SOME_RASTER.tiff",
    data=data,
    output="THE_NEW_RASTER.tiff",
    dType=float
)
```
you will not get any notification yet save a raster full of ones (1) instead of the correct float values since the arg should have been ```dtype=float``` instead of ```dType=float```. This is hard to find and usually too late.
This issue was originally created by: @chrisjwin

repository.description: Geospatial toolkit for Python
repository.name: geokit

summary.main: The main goal of the issue is to ensure that RASTER.createRaster() and RASTER.createRasterLike() properly process and validate the kwargs passed to them, preventing incorrect results and potential errors.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The kwargs passed to RASTER.createRaster() and RASTER.createRasterLike() should be processed correctly, and any false args should be detected and notified.
summary.attemptedFixes: No attempted fixes or blockers mentioned in the description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is related to RASTER.createRaster() and RASTER.createRasterLike() methods, specifically with the handling of kwargs. The description provides an example of how this can lead to incorrect results.

issueDTO.title: Recipe: Convert task ... to tasks.register(...) in build.gradle files for lazy registration
issueDTO.description:
<!--
Thank you for suggesting a new recipe for OpenRewrite!
Feel free to delete any sections that don't apply to your request.
-->

## What problem are you trying to solve?

Gradle recommends using lazy task registration (tasks.register(...)) over eager task creation (task ...) to avoid unnecessary initialization during the configuration phase, which can improve build performance and is better aligned with modern Gradle best practices. IntelliJ IDEA does offer autofix suggestions for this change, but only on a per-line basis???mass cleanup across a project is not supported via code suggestions.

## What precondition(s) should be checked before applying this recipe?

None???this change can be applied universally across all Gradle versions that support the tasks.register(...) syntax.

## Describe the situation before applying the recipe

```groovy
task allDeps(type: DependencyReportTask)
```

or

```groovy
task allDeps(type: DependencyReportTask) { 
     group = 'reporting'
     description = '...'
     // additional configuration
}
```

## Describe the situation after applying the recipe

```groovy
tasks.register("allDeps", DependencyReportTask)
```

or

```groovy
tasks.register("allDeps", DependencyReportTask) { 
     group = 'reporting'
     description = '...'
     // additional configuration
}
```

## Have you considered any alternatives or workarounds?

This can be done manually or line-by-line using IntelliJ's quick fixes, but there is currently no automated way to perform this change across an entire codebase or multiple projects.

## Any additional context

This change aligns with modern Gradle practices. While IntelliJ offers autofixes for single lines, a recipe in OpenRewrite would enable automated and large-scale migration of legacy Gradle scripts to use lazy task registration. It should be relatively straightforward to implement when needed.

## Are you interested in [contributing this recipe to OpenRewrite](https://github.com/openrewrite/.github/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#adding-new-recipes)?

Not at this time, unless prompted by customer need.
comments: Hi @Jenson3210, I'm interested in working on this issue if it's available.

Sure! Nothing here is mine 😉
If you need assistance, feel free to reach out!
- Fix PR by @jhl221123 : https://github.com/openrewrite/rewrite/pull/5492

issueDTO.title: docs: Change the data used in the getting started guide
issueDTO.description: ### Which part of the documentation needs improvement? Getting started guide example at `examples/getting_started/plot_skore_getting_started.py` ### Describe the problem found in the documentation The following dataset is used: ```python from sklearn.datasets import load_breast_cancer X, y = load_breast_cancer(return_X_y=True, as_frame=True) ``` This is a real-world dataset but it's too simple so the results look a bit too nice and it's hard to make a very compelling example usage of skore with this dataset: ### Suggested improvement Try a more difficult dataset, a synthetic but hard one, as done in the user guide at `sphinx/user_guide/displays.rst`: ```python from sklearn.datasets import make_classification from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression from skore import CrossValidationReport X, y = make_classification( n_samples=10_000, n_classes=3, class_sep=0.3, n_clusters_per_class=1, random_state=42, ) report = CrossValidationReport(LogisticRegression(), X, y) disp = report.metrics.roc() disp.plot() ``` which renders: ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d7112354-ee78-4131-aa28-907df6711e6c) ### Additional context This issue is only about changing the dataset used.

issueDTO.title: Integrate pre-commit hooks to ban large files
issueDTO.description:
Since we work with large medical images and trained models it is easy to accidentally commit large files, which then slows down CI and everyone else working on this repo.

I know of these strategies:

1. Github Enterprise has [a feature](https://help.github.com/en/enterprise/2.19/admin/installation/setting-git-push-limits) for this.
1. We could use a local git pre-commit hook.
2. We could use a remote git push hook.
2. We could add a check to Travis.
3. Maybe we could use a Github Action; they can run on more than just commits, maybe they can catch a push before it ends up in the repo.
comments:
GitHub Enterprise is out because we're not a paying customer.

Local git hooks are out, IMO, because they need to be manually installed by *everyone* on *every* machine they're working on.

Remote git hooks are out because Github won't let us do that (I think? I would love to be proven wrong). We would need to migrate to a self-hosted git server to do that. So, cool idea, but not happening.

Adding a check to CI is the only possibility I can think of. This isn't ideal because we're using a shared repo (instead of keeping separate personal forks) so once a problem file hits CI it's already in the repo and will affect everyone. But we can make it choke if your branch introduces (or has? subtle distinction) a large file in it, and have it tell you to rebase it away.

Once a file is rebased away (and it has to be [truly gone](https://help.github.com/en/github/authenticating-to-github/removing-sensitive-data-from-a-repository) -- from all branches and the `reflog` too and everyone's local copies) then `git gc` should clean it up. There's built in grace periods so it will take a while -- up to a month -- to naturally delete, but you can override them with `git reflog expire --expire=now --all` and `git gc --prune=now` and hopefully if you introduce a problem file CI can catch it before any one else checks out the branch.

Adding a check in Github Actions might be even better, because github actions can run on all sorts of events; it would be ideal if an Action would let us reject a push.
I'm very pro the Actions workflow method! It's much easier to maintain!

I'm not sure we can use `GitHub Actions` to limit file size:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/57741805/how-can-i-reject-push-from-repository-members-using-github-actions

> Local git hooks are out, IMO, because they need to be manually installed by everyone on every machine they're working on.

> Adding a check to CI is the only possibility I can think of. 

As an update, in https://github.com/shimming-toolbox/shimming-toolbox/pull/215 they went with both a local and CI check. :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:  

To get around the manual installation issue, they added [`pre-commit`](https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit) to their (optional) dev dependendies + a `.YAML` config for various [`pre-commit-hooks`](https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks). Then, they also run these hooks using GH Actions.

Just want to add on the planned workflow - if the GH Actions check gets tripped, the PR author should 1) get help from a team member with rebase know-how to perform Git surgery to excise the offending files from the branch history and 2) get set up with `pre-commit` (and generally all `dev` and `docs` dependencies) locally to prevent it from happening again.

issueDTO.title: Fold `-initlabel` functionality into the `-discfile` option
issueDTO.description:
Context: https://forum.spinalcordmri.org/t/a-few-questions-regarding-the-use-of-sct-for-quantitative-analysis-of-spinal-cord-mri/749/5

> **jcohendad:** we should probably consider getting rid of either -initlabel or -discfile to avoid confusion.

These arguments are very similar -- both are used to provide label files to replace some of the disc detection steps in the vertebral labeling algorithm. The only difference is that `-initlabel` requires that 1 disc label is provided, while `-discfile` requires that >1 disc labels are provided.

These two arguments could be merged into just `-discfile`, then a check could be performed: 

* If `num_labels == 1`, then we would do the current `-initlabel` steps
* Otherwise, there are multiple labels, and we would do the current `-discfile` steps.

issueDTO.title: `find_and_sort_coord` function handles empty-array input errors in an unclear way
issueDTO.description:
Error reported by user on the forum: https://forum.spinalcordmri.org/t/valueerror-when-using-register-to-template/867/2

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16181459/165962387-3c7b9f0d-e86b-4b37-9034-862069365d92.png)

Will update with more information if/when the user provides an image to try to reproduce the issue with.
comments: I suspect the segmentation is completely empty. If the user is not comfortable sharing the image, we could ask them to share the segmentation so we could at least verify this hypothesis.

From the error message, we know that the issue is due to `z_mean` being an empty array. 

----

`z_mean` is created here:

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/0bfc2da2eb4c2b93fa70b3b2f24d589b1932489c/spinalcordtoolbox/centerline/core.py#L106-L107

> NB: It's worth nothing that here, `im_seg` is just the image that was passed to `sct_register_to_template -s`, without any sort of resampling/preprocessing.

----

Taking a look at the [`find_and_sort_coord()`](https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/0bfc2da2eb4c2b93fa70b3b2f24d589b1932489c/spinalcordtoolbox/centerline/core.py#L61-L83) function, I found its code to be quite difficult to understand. 

So, as an exercise, I tried rewriting the function such that each step matches the comments/pseudocode a little better:

```python
    # Get [X,Y,Z] coordinates of all non-null values in the segmentation image (==> 3xN array)
    data = img_seg.data
    coord_nonnull = np.array(data.nonzero())

    # Get the dimension (0,1,2) corresponding to the SI axis
    dim_si = [img_seg.orientation.find(x) for x in ['I', 'S'] if img_seg.orientation.find(x) != -1][0]
    # Get a sorted set of non-empty SI slice numbers (==> list of size M, e.g. [23,24,25...])
    si_slices_nonnull = sorted(set(coord_nonnull[dim_si]))

    # Get the non-null coordinates within each non-empty slice (==> list of M arrays of size 3xn)
    coord_nonnull_per_si_slice = [coord_nonnull[:, coord_nonnull[dim_si] == s] for s in si_slices_nonnull]

    # Average the non-null coordinates within each non-empty slice (==> Mx3 array)
    coord_average_per_si_slice = [coord_list.mean(axis=-1) for coord_list in coord_nonnull_per_si_slice]
    return np.array(coord_average_per_si_slice).T  # .T --> (Mx3 array ==> 3xM array)
```

<details>
<summary> Sanity check against sct_testing_data </summary>

Output of the previous version:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16181459/165977407-ee47985c-f599-414e-bd09-56063ccceb0d.png)

Output of my version: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16181459/165977767-dd5df3e7-e256-41fb-9555-9ec746140db2.png)

</details>

> Note: I noticed on the [`np.where()`](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.where.html) docs, it says:
> 
> > `numpy.where(condition, [x, y, ]/)`
> >
> > When only `condition` is provided, this function is a shorthand for `np.asarray(condition).nonzero()`. Using [nonzero](https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/generated/numpy.nonzero.html#numpy.nonzero) directly should be preferred, as it behaves correctly for subclasses.
> 
> So, that's why I replaced `np.array(np.where(img.data))` with `data.nonzero()`.

----

The rewritten function suggests that if `z_mean` is an empty array, then the input segmentation must also be empty, I think? (i.e. there are no non-empty slices in the segmentation)

The main problem on our end, then, is that the `find_and_sort_coord` function didn't catch the error in a graceful way.

> I suspect the segmentation is completely empty. If the user is not comfortable sharing the image, we could ask them to share the segmentation so we could at least verify this hypothesis.

Oh! I missed your reply... I should have refreshed the page, hehe. You came to the same conclusion, but much earlier than I did. :P
Given that I'm fairly confident now that this is non-urgent, I'm going to remove this from the 5.6 milestone, and proceed with the 5.6 release (i.e. generating the 5.6 Changelog)
thank you for the thorough investigation! this is elegant detective work
A quick and easy way to solve this would be to catch an empty input seg and throw an error if that happens

issueDTO.title: Output the number of failed transformations at the end of the `moco()` function
issueDTO.description:
In `sct_fmri_moco` and `sct_dmri_moco`, when the registration algorithm does not find a transformation between adjacent time points, it uses the previous transformation (closest in time). 

In this case, the transformation function returns `1`, which gets tracked in a list variable called `failed_transfo`:

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L765-L777

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L786-L787

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L588

https://github.com/spinalcordtoolbox/spinalcordtoolbox/blob/cab82fd13425515a8568225dbe7fc003d9be2b1f/spinalcordtoolbox/moco.py#L613-L615

It would be relevant for the user, at the end of the process, to indicate how many transformations failed. (Since, while a failed transformation will emit a warning, this warning will be in the middle of processing which is easily missed.)
