issueDTO.title: Typescript version / definition files
issueDTO.description:
Hi,
I was wondering if there are any plans to eventually release a typescript version of OpenSeadragon, or at least release a .d.ts definition file.
I've found a few mentions to this topic in #456 but it appears no one is working on it.

In case anyone is interested, I started my own definition file, which you can find in this repo:
https://github.com/alvaromartmart/types-openseadragon
Bear in mind it is not complete and is based on the official documentation of v. 2.4.0 of OpenseaDragon.
If anyone is interested in collaborating, please let me know!

Whenever it is stable I would like to publish it to the [DefinitelyTyped](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped) repo or as an npm package so anyone can install it as `@types/openseadragon`
comments:
Sweet! 

I don't foresee us switching to TypeScript, or creating a parallel version in TypeScript, but if it's possible to have a sidecar file that gives optional TypeScript support to OpenSeadragon, that would be lovely!

The one you've built so far already looks pretty comprehensive. Sounds like publishing to DefinitelyTyped when you're ready is a great plan. Let me know if there's anything that would be helpful on the OSD side.  For instance I imagine it would be good to reference in the docs somewhere.
So helpful!!! Thank you!
@alvaromartmart are you still looking for help on this?

@peterlazzarino I am!
While the current state of the definition file suits my needs, there are some tasks I would like to work on at some point:
> Disclaimer: As I stated on the OP, I wrote the definition file based on the official documentation, mostly. At some points I went to the code to better understand some things that were not clear to me, but 95% was me *trusting* that the documentation is up to date with the implementation.
- [ ] Reviewing the current definitions. Maybe not thoroughly, but I don't use the whole range of OpenSeadragon features, so there are things I might have missed:
    - [ ] There are a lot of methods/constructors with optional parameters, which in my head translates to several function signatures. I tried to include as many supported signatures in the definition file, but some may be missing.
    - [ ] I don't consider myself the greatest js developer in the world, so feedback is welcome. For instance, I'm not always sure when to use an interface over a type aliases. 
- [x] There are no tests. I have not investigated yet the proper way to write ts definition file tests.
- [ ] There is just one big declaration file, it may be a good idea to spread it between several, feature-related files, and export them all together.
- [ ] OSD plugins support: I have not used any plugins yet and have not looked into how they are implemented, so I am not sure how easy it will be to include plugin definitions too.

Looking further down the road:
* I think including the code documentation in the definition file would be great, as we would be getting intellisense in VSCode and others, making it much easier to work with OpenSeadragon.
* Publishing the definition file to DefinitelyTyped, or including it on the OpenSeadragon repo itself.

So the TL; DR version is: anyone willing to help with this stuff, feel free to contact me, I'm open for collaborators ;)
Very helpful! Could you please give some brief code example for usage?
...more specifically, just the basics for gettings started, import statement and contructor basically, I can't seem to get it to work
@alvaromartmart I'm interested in collaborating to get this over the finish line into a [DefinitelyTyped](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped) PR! 🎉

@kristinruben sure! Actually, I was thinking on preparing the PR soon (maybe in the next couple of days), I'll give you the heads up when I get to it.
I will probably need some help writing some tests as recommended by the `DefinitelyTyped` guidelines.
@alvaromartmart awesome, would love to help!

@kristinruben I've created an [`openseadragon` branch in my DefinitelyTyped fork](https://github.com/alvaromartmart/DefinitelyTyped/tree/openseadragon) with the intention of preparing the PR from there.

It's already passing the linting enforced by `DefinitelyTyped`
```
cd types/openseadragon
npm run lint openseadragon
```
and can be compiled
```
tsc
```

So it's almost ready to go, the only thing is, the test file is almost empty. If you can come up with a couple of tests -keep in mind that they're not ran, only type-checked- feel free to add them to `openseadragon-tests.ts`.
Thanks @kristinruben, I just gave you collaboration permissions.

Hey, thanks for your efforts! How does it currently look like regarding types?

I'm manually creating some of the most important interfaces right now and would be super happy if I could get rid of them and just rely on the official @types definitions at some point.

I actually made a [PR to DefinitelyTyped](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/41279) a while ago so that hopefully one day we can install the types using
`
npm install @types/openseadragon
`

Unfortunately my PR seems to be stuck waiting for the first reviewer to check it again, and I have not been able to catch his/her attention.

@iangilman, as a library maintainer, maybe you could drop by the PR comments and say something? 😅

Thanks for the quick reply!

I read the comments inside of the PR you mentioned. As @RyanCavanaugh still gets mentioned as "was requested for review", it seems not correct. I don't know, but perhaps the PR state of "Changes requested" prevents the initial mentioned reviewer to get informed/have a look at it again. 5 weeks since your last adjustment seem to be quite a long time for a review. Your initial pull request was reviewed within 3 days. So I guess somebody wasn't notified and as the state of the PR is "Changes requested", they still wait for changes. So it _could be_ a good old deadlock...

However, amazing work! I just hope they move on with this.
I just realized they merged your pull request. So sweet! Do you know how this will progress from here? How will the types enter [NPM](https://www.npmjs.com/search?q=%40types%2Fopenseadragon)?
It's supposedly to be done automatically by DefinitelyTyped, I think. But I just checked and it's not yet listed in the npm registry... no idea why.

Ok, i'ts already been published: https://www.npmjs.com/package/@types/openseadragon

It still doesn't appear on search results, though. I guess they have some sort of cache.

Super nice!

Thank you very much for your amazing work and all the instant responses!

@alvaromartmart thank you for making a PR with the installation instructions; I'll get that deployed soon.

Any thoughts on how we should maintain the types going forward?

I'm working with @Dan503 on an OpenSeadragon-based comic viewer using TypeScript, and he had a few bits he needed to add to our local copy of the definitions. You can see those changes here:

https://github.com/pixfabrik/driftory-viewer/pull/5/commits/350b5560a363b76707ceb0c273bc04b134702dbe

Does that seem like a reasonable change to make to the "official" version? How do we go about that? A new PR on https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped?

> Does that seem like a reasonable change to make to the "official" version?

The exact change I made was more of a quick hack to just do the bare minimum to get my copy working so it could probably be better. I don't have enough seadragon or typescript knowledge to do a quality fix. The types in the official version should get fixed though.

> How do we go about that? A new PR

Personally I think it would be easier to just manually maintain a local `.d.ts` file as part of this repository rather than make PRs against the `@types` library. 

It would automatically get downloaded when users npm install OpenSeadragon. 

Also, if you ever make changes to the API, updating the types is as simple as updating the local file as part of the API changes. No need to make a PR against a third party repository that you don't have control over.

> Personally I think it would be easier to just manually maintain a local .d.ts file as part of this repository rather than make PRs against the @types library.

That does sound appealing! I don't know enough about the TypeScript ecosystem to know if that's a common scenario. @alvaromartmart any thoughts on that?

Yes, I think that would be much better than having to keep the types at DefinitelyTyped in sync (specially considering that OpenSeadragon releases patch versions, and DefinitelyTyped [only considers minor versions](https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped#how-do-definitely-typed-package-versions-relate-to-versions-of-the-corresponding-library) in order to determine which types correspond to the library version ).

When I have the time I'll take a look at the missing types @iangilman mentioned (sorry, I forgot about it). And I can investigate a bit more about what would imply adding the type definitions to the repo (I'm specially concerned about plugins support, but I have to check first)

@alvaromartmart (and anyone else here interested) maybe it's time to revisit moving the TypeScript definitions into this repository? With the recent 5.0.0 release, there are new APIs to provide types for ([for example](https://github.com/openseadragon/openseadragon/issues/2569#issuecomment-2292289295)), and at any rate, DefinitelyTyped versions have already drifted out of sync.

Be aware that the DefinitelyTyped library was built for the purpose of giving developers a way to define types for old JS libraries that have either been abandoned or the maintainers of the library have no interest in adding TS types to the list of their responsibilities.

If the maintainers of this library are happy to add maintaining TS types to the list of their responsibilities, then it makes the most sense for the `.d.ts` files to be added directly to this repo. The maintainers of this library should not maintain the types for their own library through DefinitelyTyped.

> @alvaromartmart (and anyone else here interested) maybe it's time to revisit moving the TypeScript definitions into this repository? With the recent 5.0.0 release, there are new APIs to provide types for ([for example](https://github.com/openseadragon/openseadragon/issues/2569#issuecomment-2292289295)), and at any rate, DefinitelyTyped versions have already drifted out of sync.

When you and I discussed this not that long ago, we decided to leave it for the time being. But as mentioned by @Dan503 I think it's appropriate for us to have the definitions as part of the library. And I agree now that v5 is out it's a good and necessary time to update the definitions. 

I have my own fork of the definitelytyped definitions that I have fixed tons of incorrect definitions and added lots of the new stuff. I use it in my projects, but it turned into such a big task I haven't been able to finish and publish it to definitely typed yet
Also, as a maintainer, I am very interested in maintaining this 😄

It's been a while now since I last used Openseadragon and honestly I don't have the time to contribute to the project nowadays but just wanted to give my 👍🏻 to moving away from DefinitelyTyped and include ts definitions in this repo, I think it makes total sense and will ensure better DX and avoid the challenges of keeping versions in sync. My only concern is that I never got to find a proper way of supporting plugins as I mentioned [here](https://github.com/openseadragon/openseadragon/issues/1628#issuecomment-732132094) but you folks will probably figure it out as you're more familiar with the codebase 🙂 .

Just for reference, here is the DefinitelyTyped OSD definition file: 

https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/blob/master/types/openseadragon/index.d.ts
BTW, does anyone know any good tools for evaluating how well the definition file matches the actual code? Going forward, how can we validate that we are keeping the definitions in sync with the code?

> @iangilman I just went through the whole thread 🧵 linked here, thanks for sharing it BTW..
> 
> I would love to try it, at least bringing the types definitions to this repo as that would significantly help everyone in maintaining it and to make contributions to it.. (as I won't be able to contribute consistently due to my other commitments) 😃
> 
> And if you could also share steps that one should do or a guide on how to run OSD build locally, that would be super helpful

@pranavgoel29 Moving the conversation here since this is where it's relevant. Thank you for working on this! 

Here's how to run locally: 

https://github.com/openseadragon/openseadragon/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md

See also:
* https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/discussions/72428
* https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/72433

Maybe someone can provide an example on how to (locally) augment the existing DefinitelyTyped declarations for own projects. I'm struggling with just adding those definitions to my own project, without repeating the complete `.d.ts` file contents.

@iangilman Thanks, already figured it out by now. But there is a questionable design decision on the TS side (https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/36146) that makes it impossible to update existing definitions when a type change is needed. For example when adding `Element` to the various `*Button` options of `Viewer`...
https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/pull/72433 has now been merged, but there are other updates needed for recent versions.

@cmahnke Cool. This is why we're talking about moving the types into OSD directly. 

@pranavgoel29 Are you still interested in working on that?

> @cmahnke Cool. This is why we're talking about moving the types into OSD directly. 
> 
> @pranavgoel29 Are you still interested in working on that?

Yes, sorry I had some busy weeks recently, I am hoping to start on this soon..
@pranavgoel29 Thanks for the update... whenever works for you 😊
@pranavgoel29 Are you still interested in working on this?

issueDTO.title: Deprecate and replace misleading method names
issueDTO.description:
Some methods have been poorly named and suggest a different behavior than the actual one. In particular, `switch_device()` and `switch_register()` suggest the device or register and switched in-place, while in reality the sequence is not modified and a new modified sequence is returned instead.

Here's a non-exhaustive list of such cases and the suggested new names:

- [ ]  `Sequence.switch_device() -> Sequence.with_new_device()`
- [ ]  `Sequence.switch_register() -> Sequence.with_new_register()`
- [ ]  `Waveform.change_duration() -> Waveform.with_new_duration()`

issueDTO.title: Default font size on small screen mobile phones is quite small
issueDTO.description:
<!--
Please discuss feature requests in the chat room or a meta thread before posting.

Issues and PRs are typically reviewed Wednesday and most weekend mornings.
-->
The default font size seems quite small on mobile phones with small screens, like iPhone SE 2nd generation, especially for the older population. Would it be possible to make it bigger or to follow the system settings?

note how in this screenshot the url text is quite bigger than the comment body text.

![IMG_3888](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/assets/361496/3e1ba3fc-ce75-43e0-9c5f-d0d8e2eb06e4)
comments: Similar to #642
IMO, even in desktop mode, it is small. I can zoom in on my laptop at least.

A larger default size for phones would be great.

There is an immediate remedy available to Mobile Safari users, which is to bump the browser text size site-wide. This is available from the page menu button on the left side of the location bar. I personally forget it exists, but it is a no-code solution. It also scales the artwork like the comment icons down the right side, which look a little too puffy after I go up one notch.

Before, 100%:

![before](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/b2d81706-14e0-47f8-a77d-a59fa01b5420)

After, 115%:

![after](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a7b7da7a-f55f-4292-a386-fa7655247e86)

An option we could consider is to apply the user's system text size setting, which is at least possible on iPhone. [Craig Hockenberry explains how to use it in CSS](https://furbo.org/2024/07/04/dynamic-type-on-the-web/). Android also has such a setting, so I wonder if browsers can offer that to pages or if they do it automatically. This would be really nice, but only after bringing text size in line with common body text.

Disclaimer: I set my system text size up to 120%, so lots of sites' text looks small to me. However, text on Lobsters looks smaller than most.

@pushcx I'm starting work on this. My proposed solution is to make the entire div which covers the both the arrow and the score clickable. That combined area is about 30px which is good enough, in contrast to the arrow alone which is 18px.

The idea is that anyone who clicks on that area wants to make a vote so it'll not obstruct any other user actions. I'll send a PR soon.
That sounds like a great approach, I look forward to your PR. I think you'll have to make the `div` and `a` to keep it working without javascript.

This [article on accessible fonts](https://accessibe.com/blog/knowledgebase/ada-compliant-fonts#character-size) recommends "A safe bet for a WCAG-conforming font size is 16px (or [1em](https://fonts.google.com/knowledge/glossary/em) or [1rem](https://blog.hubspot.com/website/css-rem))". (thanks to gj1118 on [today's office hours stream](https://push.cx/stream/2025-03-24))

Similar to how we have CSS variables for colors we reuse, we should define variables for our [font size scale](https://webtypography.net/3.1.1). The most important text on the site is the comment text, so we should pick a good size for that and pick every other size as a variation on it (headlines, bylines, header/footer, etc).

@holsta suggested a quick experiement, we removed all the `font-size` declarations, most of the `line-height`, and the `.comment_text p { padding }` and the resulting page looked quite good. There's enough variation in color and spacing that the site structure was still obvious. 

Thinking of #642 I tried moving the `comment_folder` underneath the score - the change is a bit jarring, but I think it could become comfortable with experience, it sort of fits semantically as a replacement for downvote, and it reclaims horizontal space that's especially precious on mobile.

> The most important text on the site is the comment text, so we should pick a good size for that and pick every other size as a variation on it (headlines, bylines, header/footer, etc).

I believe the most accessible and user-friendly option is to let the user dictate their preferred font size. As long as `font-size` isn't overwritten in the root element, rem units respect the browser setting for default font size. Comment text should probably have a size of 1rem while other text elements could have some other multiple of rem.

This [article on CSS units](https://www.joshwcomeau.com/css/surprising-truth-about-pixels-and-accessibility/) does a good job of explaining the issue, and it also presents some solutions to help adapt to rem units.

That sounds entirely reasonable.

I did an experiment on an office hours stream a little while ago (no link handy, sorry) where I just deleted every `font-size` from the css and the site looked quite good! We don't use many variations in font size, and the ones we have may not communicate much.

A possible remedy is to bump the browser text size site-wide, and an option to consider is to apply the user's system text size setting. ### **[Tracking] Model support**

The goal is to support other model architectures available. Expand the model zoo 🎊 

The goal is to implement support for all architectures listed below. Anyone is welcome to take any issue or implement the model below.

If you need help implementing a new model, see https://docs.sglang.ai/supported_models/support_new_models.html

#### Text-only Language Models (Generative)

- [ ] `AquilaForCausalLM` (Aquila, Aquila2)
- [ ] `ArcticForCausalLM` (Arctic) #5768
- [ ] `BambaForCausalLM` (Bamba)
- [ ] `BartForConditionalGeneration` (BART)
- [ ] `BloomForCausalLM` (BLOOM, BLOOMZ)
- [ ] `Cohere2ForCasualLM` #4570
- [ ] `DeciLMForCausalLM` (DeciLM)
- [ ] `FalconForCausalLM` (Falcon)
- [ ] `FalconH1ForCausalLM` (Falcon-H1) #6517

issueDTO.title: kube play not able to mount podman secret as a file
issueDTO.description:
### Issue Description

I am trying to mount a podman secret as a file using kube play, however an error is being produced:
`Error: failed to create volume "my-volume": error unmarshaling JSON: while decoding JSON: json: cannot unmarshal string into Go value of type v1.Secret`

### Steps to reproduce the issue

Steps to reproduce the issue - I am using rootless podman
1. Create a text file: 
`echo "My Secret File" >> my_secret_file.txt`
2. Create a secret from the file:
`podman secret create my-secret-file ./my_secret_file.txt`
3. Create a kube.yaml file: mytest.yaml
```
apiVersion: v1
kind: Pod
metadata:
  annotations:
  labels:
    app: mytest
  name: mytest
spec:
  containers:
  - image: registry.access.redhat.com/ubi9-minimal:latest
    command: ["sleep 1000"]
    name: app
    securityContext:
      runAsNonRoot: true
    volumeMounts:
    - mountPath: /my_secret_file.txt
      name: my-volume
  volumes:
  - name: my-volume
    secret:
      secretName: my-secret-file
```
4. Run the file
`podman kube play mytest.yaml`

### Describe the results you received

I received an error:

```
Error: failed to create volume "my-volume": error unmarshaling JSON: while decoding JSON: json: cannot unmarshal string into Go value of type v1.Secret
```

### Describe the results you expected

I would have expected for the pod/container to run and be able to look into the pod and see a file:
`/my_secret_file.txt`

### podman info output

```yaml

      host_id: 231072
      size: 65536

### Privileged Or Rootless

### Upstream Latest Release

No

### Additional environment details

_No response_

### Additional information

While this is a trivial example, the real use case is that we create podman secrets for a servers cert/key/ca and mount them into a container to be used.
comments:
k8s has its own concept of secrets, the way the interface is works as that the k8s expects a secret to be create via the k8s file as well

see the secret example in the man page https://docs.podman.io/en/stable/markdown/podman-kube-play.1.html#description

Because k8s secrets seem to have several key/value pairs the secret content it creates is a json marshal that we then try to unmarshal into our type which fails here, we could certainly improve the error message here but as I understand the code it is not supposed to work as k8s can only use the secrets created via the yaml file not via podman secret create.

Thank you.  That put me onto the correct path.

For anyone else trying to do this, here is how you can create the secret without having kubectl available:

Create template for the secret:
```
# mysecret.yml.tmpl
apiVersion: v1
kind: Secret
metadata:
  name: my-secret
type: Opaque
data:
  my_secret_file.txt: FILE_CONTENT
```

Generate the podman secret:
```
sed "s/FILE_CONTENT/`cat /my/secret/place/my_secret_file.txt|base64 -w0`/g" mysecret.yml.tmpl | podman kube play -
Secrets:
088e5406ff8cb48fbb5df5b3a
```

See it:
```
podman secret ls
ID                         NAME        DRIVER      CREATED         UPDATED
088e5406ff8cb48fbb5df5b3a  my-secret   file        25 seconds ago  25 seconds ago

I think we should keep this open just to fix the error message at least. A random json unmarshal error message is not useful to the end user. The message should say that only secrets created via the kube yaml file are supported.

issueDTO.title: Fix sequence of events when "Custom command" and "Working directory" are defined together
issueDTO.description:
When a custom layout is created 

Having a `Terminal` type is possible define together:

* Custom command
* Working directory

I did do realize with a simple command such as `ls` that it works according with the `/home/<username>` path and not according with the `Working directory`. Therefore the current sequence is:

* Execute the `Custom command` according with `/home/<username>`
* Move to the  `Working directory`

But should be:

* Move to the  `Working directory`
* Execute the `Custom command` according with `Working directory`

Of course for other command which does not depend of the working directory such as `date` it is not an issue but for the other scenario yes.

repository.description: multiple GNOME terminals in one window
repository.name: terminator

summary.main: Fix sequence of events when `Custom command` and `Working directory` are defined together
summary.validationOrRequirement: The sequence of events should be: Move to the `Working directory`, then Execute the `Custom command` according with `Working directory`.
summary.attemptedFixes: None mentioned in the description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: When a custom layout is created, having a `Terminal` type is possible define together: Custom command and Working directory. The issue is with the current sequence of events, which executes the Custom command according with `/home/<username>` path and then moves to the Working directory. It should be the other way around.

issueDTO.title: Add MinMaxScaler Estimator
issueDTO.description:
The MinMaxScaler estimator scales the data to a range set by the minimum and maximum. Use the IncrementalBasicStatistics 
estimator to generate the min and max to scale the data. Investigate where the new implementation may be low performance and 
include guards in the code to use Scikit-learn as necessary. The final deliverable would be to add this estimator to the 'spmd'
interfaces which are effective on MPI-enabled supercomputers, this will use the underlying MPI-enabled minimum and maximum
calculators in IncrementalBasicStatistics. This is similar to the MaxAbsScaler and can be combined into a small project.
This is an easy difficulty project.

https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.preprocessing.MinMaxScaler.html
comments:
Hi @icfaust  thank you for opening this issue ??? it looks really interesting and I'd love to explore contributing to it.

I have a basic understanding of Min-Max normalization and the general idea behind preprocessing scalers like MinMaxScaler. However, this would be my first open-source contribution, and I???m new to the distributed implementations (like with spmd and MPI).

Before I commit to working on this, could you please help me with:
- An estimate of how much time it might take to implement this, considering I???m a beginner.
- A list of topics, tools, or parts of the codebase you???d recommend I understand first.
- Any existing examples (like MaxAbsScaler) that could help me get started.

I want to make sure I approach this responsibly and with the right preparation. Appreciate any guidance you can offer!
Thanks again ??? looking forward to your suggestions.

Hello @meher-chinmaya Thanks for reaching out!  From our ideas page (https://uxlfoundation.github.io/scikit-learn-intelex/latest/ideas.html) we list this as requiring 90 hours to complete, where the majority of the time will be spent learning the nuances of how we write our sklearnex Estimators.  

Recommended reading would be the
2) Understand the sklearnex estimator design via this PR: https://github.com/uxlfoundation/scikit-learn-intelex/pull/2534 (this is still a work in progress, and sorry about its current state)
3) Understand the sklearn estimator implementation here: (https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/blob/da08f3d99/sklearn/preprocessing/_data.py#L295) and understand where the IncrementalBasicStatistics onedal estimator can be used instead of sklearn
4) Read up on our IncrementalBasicStatistics onedal estimator: https://github.com/uxlfoundation/scikit-learn-intelex/blob/main/onedal/basic_statistics/incremental_basic_statistics.py

It would be pioneering a lot of new functionality in the code, so I will be able to walk you through it as we go along.  Thanks for reaching out and let me know if you have any more questions.

Thank you so much for the detailed response and the helpful reading material.
I really appreciate the guidance and clarity. After reviewing the estimated time commitment and the scope of work, I???ve realized that I may not be able to dedicate the 90 hours required at the moment, especially with this being my first contribution. I???d rather not commit unless I can give it the attention it deserves.

After creating a process application I want to be able to save my next diagram relative to the folder, but it is not stored as "last save context".

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a process application in folder `X`
2. Create a new diagram, save it
3. I expect that the save dialog starts from folder `X`, instead it opens from wherever I last saved


### Expected behavior

When I create a process application in folder `X`, then `X` is suggested for me as a save destination.

### Environment

- OS: Linux
- Camunda Modeler Version: v5.34.0-rc.4
- Execution Platform: Camunda 8
- Installed plug-ins: None


### Additional context

None.
comments: The issue is that because you can only select folders when creating a process application and therefore only the parent folder of the process application file that the parent folder is saved as the default path. I need to check whether this can be qick fixed.
If it's a quick fix, let's do that. If not, we can move it to the backlog / spring cleaning.

issueDTO.title: Generate a kube diagram for only one namespace
issueDTO.description:
Hello,

Thank you for this great tool!

I'm trying to generate a diagram for a single Kubernetes namespace. Is there a way to limit the scope of the diagram to just one namespace?

Here???s what I???ve tried so far:
- Running `kube-diagrams` without any filters includes all namespaces.
- I didn???t find a `--namespace` or similar flag in the documentation.

Use case:
I'd like to visualize only the resources inside a namespace (e.g., `my-app`) to reduce noise and make it easier to share diagrams with teams focused on specific components.

Is there a way to do this currently? If not, would this be a feature you would consider adding?

Thanks in advance!
comments: @Ben-Sassi-Oussema We will address this asap.
@Ben-Sassi-Oussema a --namespace option was added to kube-diagrams. Thank you to try it to check that this addresses your needs.

I tested the new feature and it works using the following command line:
"kubectl get all -n test -o yaml | kube-diagrams -o test.png -"
In my app, I have a Deployment, Service, and Ingress, and I can see the Ingress in the generated diagram.

issueDTO.title: libc: implement `getc()`
issueDTO.description:
This was originally added as a ticket under POSIX, but `getc()` is not a POSIX function. It is from C89.

https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/io/fgetc

The expectation from the POSIX API is that this function is implemented as part of whatever C library is in use.
comments: Is this not already in the minimal libc??
Hej @ycsin, @cfriedt, If this issue is not worked, I would like to take this. It would be helpful if you can guide and share some reference about this issue.

> I would like to take this. It would be helpful if you can guide and share some reference about this issue.

Hi @00thirdeye00 - `getc(FILE *stream)` shouldn't be too difficult.

From a very high level, it should be as simple as 
1. lock the fdtable entry associated with `stream` (and verify that it is valid)
2. read a character and report it back, or `EOF` if there is an error.
3. unlock the fdtable entry

Do we still have `zvfs_read()` or was that reverted? With that, it would be trivial to implement.
@cfriedt hej, thank you, since i am new to zephyr, it can be helpful if you can provide any references to files, implementation and flow

@00thirdeye00 -

lib/os/fdtable.c <-- ftdable and some ZVFS functions
lib/c_lib/common/ <-- common libc components

https://docs.zephyrproject.org/latest/contribute/index.html
@00thirdeye00 @cfriedt has anybody started to work on this issue? Or can I take it?

> [@00thirdeye00](https://github.com/00thirdeye00) [@cfriedt](https://github.com/cfriedt) has anybody started to work on this issue? Or can I take it?

Please feel free to do so.

- For a typical file, refer to @cfriedt comment above.
- For `stdin`, we need to somehow hook the console UART with the libc, but I'm quite confused with the implementation of `drivers/console/uart_console.c` - it looks kinda ad-hoc and probably needs to be detangled from the mcumgr handlers, the `subsys/console` might also need some rework. I was actually looking into that ytd (https://github.com/ycsin/zephyr/commit/ef0f8264261ba8672df2d346bbd24d1799df0737).

- Guess the `getc()` implementation would go under libc/minimal. And the definition would be `int getc(FILE* stream);`
- It sounds like that `FILE` handle could be possibly either file or UART handle?

> * Guess the `getc()` implementation would go under libc/minimal.

Yes, if it is only used by minimal libc. If it's going to be shared by other libc then probably `lib/libc/common`

> And the definition would be `int getc(FILE* stream);`

Yes, you can read more about the definition here: https://en.cppreference.com/w/c/io/fgetc

> * It sounds like that `FILE` handle could be possibly either file or UART handle?

Anything that can be read from or written to can be abstracted as a 'FILE'
Sounds good.

I'm thinking to design and implement `getc()` using the same pattern as `putc()`. The design patten used for `putc()` leverages hooks(`_stdout_hook` for output) to abstract platform-specific behaviors. Similarly, `getc()` can use a `_stdin_hook` mechanism for input.

repository.description: Primary Git Repository for the Zephyr Project. Zephyr is a new generation, scalable, optimized, secure RTOS for multiple hardware architectures.
repository.name: zephyr

summary.main: Implement the getc() function, which should lock the fdtable entry associated with the stream, read a character and report it back, or EOF if there is an error, and unlock the fdtable entry.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The function should be implemented as part of the C library, as per POSIX API expectations.
summary.attemptedFixes: The design pattern used for putc() can be leveraged to implement getc() using _stdin_hook mechanism for input.
summary.otherNotes: The implementation should be under libc/minimal if only used by minimal libc, otherwise under lib/libc/common. The FILE handle can be either a file or UART handle. The function can be designed and implemented using the same pattern as putc().

Open reports

**Welcome to the EMBA firmware analysis community!**

We are glad you are here and appreciate your contribution. Please keep in mind our contributing guidelines [here](https://github.com/e-m-b-a/embark/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) and [here](https://github.com/e-m-b-a/embark/blob/master/CONTRIBUTORS.md).
Also, please check [existing open issues](https://github.com/e-m-b-a/embark/issues) and consider to open a discussion in the dedicated [discussion area](https://github.com/e-m-b-a/embark/discussions).
Additionally, we have collected a lot of details around EMBArk, the installation and the usage of EMBArk in our [Wiki](https://github.com/e-m-b-a/embark/wiki).

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d8fdbfe3-0c8b-4bc0-8865-05600b125283)

issueDTO.title: 🚀 Feature: Use the Catalog presentation API
issueDTO.description:
### 🔖 Feature description

Now that #17474 is merged, let's use the presentation APIs all over the place! This should help with ensuring that entities are presented uniformly with their titles / display names / etc, and with the same iconography everywhere if applicable.



### 🎤 Context

See #17474

### ?????? Possible Implementation

Places in the code that use `EntityRefLink`/`EntityRefLinks` are already covered.

But there's still a fair number of places that just plain render `metadata.name`, or use `humanizeEntityRef`, or use some custom logic like that. Those should generally try to use the `EntityDisplayName` React component if possible, or use `EntityPresentation.promise` when in non-React code (which becomes available after #24595 is merged).

We'd appreciate the help with digging through the Backstage core and plugins, finding places where the presentation API should be used.

### 👀 Have you spent some time to check if this feature request has been raised before?

- [X] I checked and didn't find similar issue

### 🏢 Have you read the Code of Conduct?

- [X] I have read the [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/backstage/backstage/blob/master/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

### Are you willing to submit PR?

No, but I'm happy to collaborate on a PR with someone else
comments: Hi there, could I take up this one? Thanks!

It's free for anyone to chip away at! Several small PRs is probably better than one large - easier to review. And it's probably going to take a few stabs before it's complete so may be worth not assigning to a single person perhaps 🤔

I see, I was acquainted with other projects to ask for assignment firstly and not aware of contribution etiquette here

Let me take a stab at it. Thanks!

No worries, glad you asked! A lot of times we do assign to avoid trampling on each others' feet, but this one may be diverse enough to try leaving it out to begin with. Let's try and then reevaluate if needed!

Hi @freben , I would love to help out this issue. After reviewing the codebase, I have a couple of questions.

- Since humanizeEntityRef is a function returning a string, how is it suggested to replace EntityDisplayName, which is a React component?
- I have lookup the place using EntityDisplayName, but I can't figure out how it related to the usage of humanizeEntityRef.

Thank you for the patience!

Hi!

Yeah as I alluded to in the issue description "There are some cases where you aren't yet in a React tree"; those cases may need some rewriting where possible (moving work out of a function and instead into a child helper component or similar), or if you find that this isn't working out at all, we'd like to see examples of those cases to see if there's something we should do to extend or alter the API interface to cater to those cases.

Essentially, the _desired_ end result is that there's no custom rendering of `humanizeEntityRef` or plain `metadat.name` and similar anywhere. Getting all the way there may or may not need alterations to the presentation API.

EDIT: https://github.com/backstage/backstage/pull/24595 adds the promise based API

issueDTO.title: Feature: By default, require only self-signed certificates in a bundle
issueDTO.description:
Writing down what occurred to me at the end of the cert-manager biweekly meeting on 28/07

An issue with administering trust bundles is that it's very easy + tempting for users to put intermediates in the trust store as a way of "fixing" trust issues. Usually this occurs when an app is buggy and only sends the leaf certificate without its chain, and explicitly trusting the leaf's issuing intermediate CA seems to fix the problem for them. Crucially, when that intermediate is then rotated their app will break.

We could add a toggle, defaulting to false, such as `allowIntermediateCertificates`. If false, it would parse every certificate and ensure that it's self-signed. There might be other ways of achieving the same goal.

Having this in from the start could prevent so many misconfigurations by unsuspecting cluster admins.

(Complication: If we added a list of publicly trusted certs it'd probably need to default to allowing intermediates in that list by default - but we could definitely default to disallowing intermediates everywhere else)
comments: This would disallow cross signing roots. While probably a good default, it shouldn't be added without the toggle.

Somehow related to https://github.com/cert-manager/trust-manager/issues/155, at least the changes would touch overlapping areas of code.

/good-first-issue

/remove-good-first-issue

At least if we like to enable this by default - which could break some users.

Updating with my latest thoughts on this: I probably wouldn't want to enable this by default, but I still think it's a nice option to have. Enabling by default would be too breaking to roll out, and I don't think it's worth it because of the risk of catching cross-signed certs or other valid non-self-signed certs.
While looking at how to implement this, I wonder if we should just ignore any non-self-signed certificate or should we error out. Any thoughts here @SgtCoDFish?

I think a hard error would be pretty destructive - if I added a non-self-signed cert by mistake to a bundle I'd probably want a warning at most. Non-self-signed certs aren't immediately harmful or anything - they're just a smell that something harmful might happen later.

(There are also cases - e.g. cross signing - where I'd want a non-self-signed cert in the trust bundle and wouldn't want to be warned about it!)

> I think a hard error would be pretty destructive - if I added a non-self-signed cert by mistake to a bundle I'd probably want a warning at most. Non-self-signed certs aren't immediately harmful or anything - they're just a smell that something harmful might happen later.

So in case a user enables this new feature, we should just filter out any non-self-signed cert and emit a warning?

repository.description: trust-manager is an operator for distributing trust bundles across a Kubernetes cluster.
repository.name: trust-manager

summary.main: Require only self-signed certificates in a trust bundle by default, with an option to allow intermediate certificates.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The toggle would ensure that all certificates in the trust bundle are self-signed, with a warning for non-self-signed certificates.
summary.attemptedFixes: Consider adding a toggle, defaulting to false, such as allowIntermediateCertificates. If false, it would parse every certificate and ensure that it's self-signed.
summary.otherNotes: An issue with administering trust bundles is that it's very easy + tempting for users to put intermediates in the trust store as a way of 'fixing' trust issues. Crucially, when that intermediate is then rotated their app will break. Having this in from the start could prevent so many misconfigurations by unsuspecting cluster admins.

issueDTO.title: Map-Filter-Reduce for Rust and/or C++
issueDTO.description:
Transmuting pointers, using `unsafe` sections, and padding elements to different cache lines is quite tricky in Rust, and not always straightforward & safe in C++ too. The following "map-reduce"-like operations can be introduced:

```rs
pub fn try_map<T, U, F>(
    &self,
    inputs: &[T],
    map: F,
) -> Result<Vec<Padding64<U>, A>, ForkUnionError>
where ...
```

The full set of operations may include: `try_map`, `try_map_reduce`, `try_map_filter_reduce`. The `try_map_reduce` and `try_map_filter_reduce` should be much cheaper to run, than combining `try_map` with subsequent separate reduction. In optimized versions, we can keep just one "folding reduction result" privately per thread, and can be outputted into a smaller container the size of the thread pool - no the `inputs` container.

Relevant considerations:

- What kinds of `inputs` containers can be accepted, and have sub-linear iteration cost, so that we can cheaply split the work between multiple worker threads?
- Should we use the same allocator with which the `ForkUnion` was created or allow passing an additional one for the exported execution results?
- For non-flat `inputs`, should the method be called `try_flat_map`?
comments: can I please take it up?
Of course, @etimofeeva! Sorry, didn't see this earlier 🤗
Hi @etimofeeva! Any progress on this one?

repository.description: Low(est?)-latency OpenMP-style minimalistic scoped thread-pool designed for 'Fork-Join' parallelism in Rust and C++, avoiding memory allocations, mutexes, CAS-primitives, and false-sharing on the hot path 🍴
repository.name: fork_union

summary.main: Introduce map-filter-reduce operations in Rust and/or C++ for efficient and safe processing of complex data structures.
summary.validationOrRequirement: The issue requires consideration of sub-linear iteration cost for input containers, and possibly using the same allocator as the ForkUnion or allowing an additional one for exported results.
summary.attemptedFixes: No specific attempted fixes or blockers mentioned in the issue description or comments.
summary.otherNotes: The issue aims to introduce map-filter-reduce operations in Rust and/or C++ for transmuting pointers, using unsafe sections, and padding elements to different cache lines. Relevant considerations include input container types, allocator usage, and method naming for non-flat inputs.

issueDTO.title: [Android] `Invariant.Tests.csproj` is failing on CoreCLR Android
issueDTO.description:
### Description

The `System.Globalization.Tests/Invariant/Invariant.Tests.csproj` fails on CoreCLR Android because the invariant-globalization flag isn't propagated to the runtime at startup. The project file contains
```
<InvariantGlobalization>true</InvariantGlobalization>
```
but the CoreCLR initialization code in `monodroid-coreclr.c` does not forward this setting as an appcontext variable, so the runtime never runs in invariant-globalization mode.

### Reproduction Steps

Build the runtime:
```
build.sh -arch arm64 -os android  -s clr.runtime+clr.alljits+clr.corelib+clr.nativecorelib+clr.tools+clr.packages+libs+libs.tests+host+packs -c Release /p:ArchiveTests=true /p:RunSmokeTestsOnly=True
```

Run the apk using Android Studio.

### Expected behavior

The tests pass on the CI: https://dev.azure.com/dnceng-public/public/_build?definitionId=223

### Actual behavior

The tests fail on the CI.
comments:
Tagging subscribers to this area: @hoyosjs
See info in [area-owners.md](https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/area-owners.md) if you want to be subscribed.
<!-- Policy app identification https://img.shields.io/static/v1?label=PullRequestIssueManagement. -->

As part of this we should also check if the properties work in dotnet/android SDK - so basically build a sample app which sets a property like this and build it with the full SDK with `UseMonoRuntime=false` and validate that the property is correctly propagated to the runtime. @grendello mentioned in a chat with me that this seems to be potentially broken as well. So let's check both places at once.

issueDTO.title: --no-web Packaging Option
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing proposal for this?

- [X] I have searched the existing proposals

### Is your feature request related to a problem?

I have an issue utilizing the flamegraph and table output options when using memray on an airgapped system. Since the system does not have internet access, connecting to the CDNs to get the javascript is not possible and the web pages aren't fully loaded.

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would like it if memray would in a `--no-web` packaging option that would include the necessary html/css/js files as part of memray and have the the generated html to point accordingly.

### Alternatives you considered

Putting the files on the air gapped system and changing the links the html to point to the local file system path.
comments: I'd like to take the task of making a PR for this but am a little lost on how to best go about funneling it through to ultimately make say a conda package that has this option

Honestly, I'm not sure what work is required here either. The biggest part of any PR here is likely figuring out exactly what files are fetched dynamically by our flame graphs as they exist today (using the developer tools of the browser should be able to get us this), and then figuring out what would be involved in vendoring a copy of those into the Memray repo. Once we have a vendored copy of each of those dependencies, it should "just" be a matter of exposing a switch that changes whether our Jinja templates include URLs linking to external resources or include the contents of those resources directly.

If we find that some of these dependencies are difficult to vendor, or have licenses that are incompatible with us vendoring them instead of loading them dynamically, this might be a nonstarter.

Flamegraph report:

Bootstrap - MIT License - https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/main/LICENSE
JQuery - MIT License - https://jquery.org/license
Lodash - MIT License - https://lodash.com/license
plotly.js - MIT license - https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/LICENSE
popper.js(now Floating UI) - MIT License - https://github.com/floating-ui/floating-ui/blob/v2.x/LICENSE.md
d3 - ISC License - https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/main/LICENSE
d3-flamegraph - Apache License 2.0 - https://github.com/spiermar/d3-flame-graph/blob/master/LICENSE
d3-scale-chromatic - Not clear - https://github.com/d3/d3-scale-chromatic/blob/main/LICENSE
d3-tip - MIT License - https://github.com/caged/d3-tip/blob/master/LICENSE

Table report:

Datatables - MIT License - https://datatables.net/license/mit
I have a prototype solution ready for this issue. Can I go ahead and submit a PR? If possible, could anyone assign this issue to me?

> could anyone assign this issue to me?

Done

> Can I go ahead and submit a PR?

Go ahead! Bear in mind that it may take a bit more than normal for us to review the PR because we need to review more carefully the vending code due to licensing and other aspects.

> Bootstrap - MIT License - https://github.com/twbs/bootstrap/blob/main/LICENSE JQuery - MIT License - https://jquery.org/license Lodash - MIT License - https://lodash.com/license plotly.js - MIT license - https://github.com/plotly/plotly.js/blob/master/LICENSE popper.js(now Floating UI) - MIT License - https://github.com/floating-ui/floating-ui/blob/v2.x/LICENSE.md d3 - ISC License - https://github.com/d3/d3/blob/main/LICENSE d3-flamegraph - Apache License 2.0 - https://github.com/spiermar/d3-flame-graph/blob/master/LICENSE d3-scale-chromatic - Not clear - https://github.com/d3/d3-scale-chromatic/blob/main/LICENSE d3-tip - MIT License - https://github.com/caged/d3-tip/blob/master/LICENSE

issueDTO.title: Avoid excessive use of `toarray` in unit tests
issueDTO.description:
Many of our unit tests compute the 2-norm of an error vector and compare it to a given tolerance. To this aim, unfortunately, they often convert a Psydac vector to a NumPy array, which is unnecessarily expensive:
```python
error = a - b
assert np.linalg.norm(error.toarray()) < TOL
```
Instead, the same result can be obtained by using the method `inner` of our `Vector` objects, without any unnecessary memory allocation:
```python
# Define 2-norm of vector using inner
norm2 = lambda v: sqrt(v.inner(v))

error = a - b
assert norm2(error) < TOL
```
comments:
While refactoring the `test_operator_evaluation` function (`/linalg/tests/test_linalg.py`) to remove all `.toarray() `(to better leverage PSYDAC???s native vector/matrix structures and improve efficiency), I noticed that the current computation of the variable `error_est` relies on a full dense inverse via:

```
Bmat = B.toarray()

B_inv_mat = np.linalg.inv(Bmat)
b_inv_arr = np.matrix.flatten(B_inv_mat)
error_est = 2 + n1 * n2 * np.max([np.abs(b_inv_arr[i]) for i in range(len(b_inv_arr))])

```
Since we???re avoiding those dense NumPy operations for performance and memory reasons, I believe this calculation of `error_est` no longer fits well in the new context. Computing the full inverse matrix is computationally expensive and somewhat contradictory to the iterative sparse methods we???re testing.

Could you suggest an alternative approach for `error_est`?
For example, I???m considering replacing it with a simpler, lightweight estimate such as:

`error_est = {some num > 0}* n1 * n2`

This is an error estimate based on the maximum absolute value of the inverse matrix. It could read in fact
```python
error_est = np.linalg.norm(Bmat.flat, np.inf)
```
which is the inf-norm of the vectorized matrix. This does not seem to give a sharp estimate, given that it is multiplied by a small number just below (`tol = 1e-5`). Maybe @jowezarek could shed some light on this?

@anushkasinghh @yguclu 
Thanks for bringing this up, this code snipped is ridiculously complicated and doesn't do what it's supposed to do :')

The explicit matrix inverse was never truly needed, and yet there's no time to gain as the entire test ran in < 3 seconds on my machine.

This particular part of the test was designed to test whether power operations (**0, **1, **2) work with inverse linear operators (ILOs).

The poorly executed idea of the test was the following:
```python
# arbitrary tolerance
tol = 

# Define 2-norm of vector using inner (as proposed by Yaman)
norm2 = lambda v: sqrt(v.inner(v))

# Psydac objects, solver with tolerance = tol
u
B_ILO = inverse(B, 'cg', tol=tol)

# First test: Check whether B_ILO**0 is the identity matrix (B_ILO**0 = id?)

error = (B_ILO**0) @ u - u
assert norm2(error) < 1e-15 # error should really be zero

# Second test: Check whether B_ILO**1 really computes the inverse up to accuracy (B_ILO**1 = B_ILO?)
# I.e., we expect B @ B_ILO**1 @ u to be equal to u + err, err a vector of norm less than tol

error = B @ B_ILO**1 @ u - u
assert norm2(error) < tol

# Third test: Now checking whether B_ILO**2 is really equal to a double application of B_ILO (B_ILO**2 = B_ILO @ B_ILO?)
# B @ B @ B_ILO @ B_ILO @ u = B @ ( B_ILO @ u + err1 ) = u + err2 + B @ err1
# where both err1 and err2 are vectors of norm less than tol, hence
# | B @ B @ B_ILO @ B_ILO @ u - u | = | err2 + B @ err1 | < | err2 | + | B @ err1 | < tol + |B|_{inf} * tol = (1 + |B|_{inf}) * tol

adjusted_tol = ( 1 + np.max(np.abs(B.toarray())) ) * tol
error = B @ B @ B_ILO**2 @ u - u
assert norm2(error) < adjusted_tol

So if I understand correctly, the old error estimate was:
```
error_est = 2 + n1 * n2 * np.max([np.abs(b_inv_arr[i]) for i in range(len(b_inv_arr))])
assert norm2((B @ bi22) - bi12) < error_est * tol
```

@jowezarek 's suggestion improves this by incorporating a more accurate error bound:
```
error_est = (1 + norm(B)) * tol # or error_est = (1 + np.max(np.abs(B.toarray())) ) * tol
error = B @ B @ B_ILO**2 @ u - u
assert norm2(error) < error_est

```
This should yield a more reliable tolerance without significant performance cost.

summary.main: Refactor the `test_operator_evaluation` function to remove all `.toarray()` and improve efficiency, and suggest an alternative approach for `error_est`
summary.validationOrRequirement: The goal is to avoid excessive use of `toarray` in unit tests, and to leverage PSYDAC's native vector/matrix structures and improve efficiency.
summary.attemptedFixes: The alternative approach for error_est is to replace it with a simpler, lightweight estimate such as error_est = {some num > 0}* n1 * n2, or error_est = np.linalg.norm(Bmat.flat, np.inf).
summary.otherNotes: The explicit matrix inverse was never truly needed, and yet there's no time to gain as the entire test ran in < 3 seconds on my machine. The test was designed to test whether power operations (**0, **1, **2) work with inverse linear operators (ILOs).

issueDTO.title: Add Support for Dynamic "s3_bucket" in data routing based on resource attributes
issueDTO.description:
### Component(s)

exporter/awss3

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

We want to separate data storage at the bucket level in S3, based on resource attributes. Currently, this requires us to configure a new exporter each time a new bucket is introduced, which becomes difficult to manage at scale.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Since dynamic "s3_prefix" support already exists, it would be great to extend this functionality to also support "s3_bucket", allowing the bucket name to be derived from resource attributes dynamically.

### Describe alternatives you've considered

_No response_

### Additional context

I'm not very familiar with Go, so I'm hoping the owners can take this on. I assume this feature would be relatively straightforward to implement, given that similar logic already exists for s3_prefix.

issueDTO.title: Extend type hints in the classifiers and regressors
issueDTO.description:
<!-- ?????? If you do not respect this template, your issue will be closed -->
<!-- ?????? Make sure to browse the opened and closed issues to confirm this idea does not exist. -->

### What is the expected behavior?
Since we are going to introduce categorical labels (and perhaps categorical features), I think, we can re-consider type hints for the classifiers and regressors and make them more like in Scikit-Learn: `array_like`. This may allow to pass plain lists or other types. As an example take a look at the interface here: https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.linear_model.LinearRegression.html

This issue is just for discussion.
comments: @adekusar-drl, could you please share an example or template of how you'd match the SKlearn type hinting for QML?

It has been a low priority for a long time, things might have changed. While scikit learn does not expose type hints by default, one of the possible options to take a look at https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/typing.html#module-numpy.typing. Numpy has `ArrayLike` type hint and it may work. This issue is more exploratory one rather something that can be easily implemented. Even if numpy's hinting is good enough, I'd first double check if such hinting brings in any value, not problems.

For instance
https://github.com/qiskit-community/qiskit-machine-learning/blob/c59063af02afbb56cfdb27408068aa1c0f5bc718/qiskit_machine_learning/algorithms/classifiers/pegasos_qsvc.py#L128-L130
would become
```python
import numpy.typing as npt

def fit( 
     self, X: npt.ArrayLike, y: npt.ArrayLike, sample_weight: npt.ArrayLike | None = None 
 ) -> "PegasosQSVC": 
```
or, more strictly,
```python
import numpy.typing as npt

def fit( 
     self, X: npt.NDArray[np.float64], y: npt.NDArray[np.float64], sample_weight: npt.NDArray[np.float64] | None = None 
 ) -> "PegasosQSVC": 
```
While young, the new typing in Numpy is covered by tests and CI, and made it into a major release. So I'd consider the basic features relatively stable.

Mypy can also be configured to account for strongly typed Numpy objects as
```
[mypy]
plugins = numpy.typing.mypy_plugin
```
See https://numpy.org/doc/stable/reference/typing.html .
Can i work in this issue ?

summary.attemptedFixes: The author suggests trying to match the sklearn type hinting for QML, using numpy's hinting, and configuring mypy to account for strongly typed numpy objects.
summary.otherNotes: The issue is exploratory and may not be easily implemented, requires checking if type hinting brings value or problems, numpy's hinting may be a good option, the author suggests trying to match the sklearn type hinting for QML, the issue is more for discussion than implementation.

issueDTO.title: Don't suggest importing internal modules
issueDTO.description:
Currently, the "import module" code action will suggest importing internal modules from other packages:
```gleam
pub fn main() {
  internal_module.something() // Suggests "import `some_package/internal_module`"
}
```
We do not want this. The code action should only suggest public modules from other packages

issueDTO.title: [DAG] SDPatternMatch - m_Zero can't see through bitcasts
issueDTO.description:
X86 uses ISD::isBuildVectorAllZeros to peek through bitcasts to match zero vectors in a large number of combines.

Ideally we'd use SDPatternMatch to match these combines and use m_Zero() instead, but regrettably this fails to match the zero vectors through bitcasts,

https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commit/84397c61f44e62231d1876a745a0c1f74ea8a5b8 shows an example of the regression

If we convert m_Zero() to something closer to m_AllOnes / AllOnes_match we might be able to make this work.
comments:
Hi!

This issue may be a good introductory issue for people new to working on LLVM. If you would like to work on this issue, your first steps are:

1. Check that no other contributor has already been assigned to this issue. If you believe that no one is actually working on it despite an assignment, ping the person. After one week without a response, the assignee may be changed.
1. In the comments of this issue, request for it to be assigned to you, or just create a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) after following the steps below. [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.
1. Fix the issue locally.
1. [Run the test suite](https://llvm.org/docs/TestingGuide.html#unit-and-regression-tests) locally. Remember that the subdirectories under `test/` create fine-grained testing targets, so you can e.g. use `make check-clang-ast` to only run Clang's AST tests.
1. Create a Git commit.
1. Run [`git clang-format HEAD~1`](https://clang.llvm.org/docs/ClangFormat.html#git-integration) to format your changes.
1. Open a [pull request](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/pulls) to the [upstream repository](https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project) on GitHub. Detailed instructions can be found [in GitHub's documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/pull-requests/collaborating-with-pull-requests/proposing-changes-to-your-work-with-pull-requests/creating-a-pull-request). [Mention](https://docs.github.com/en/issues/tracking-your-work-with-issues/linking-a-pull-request-to-an-issue) this issue in the description of the pull request.

If you have any further questions about this issue, don't hesitate to ask via a comment in the thread below.

@llvm/issue-subscribers-good-first-issue

Author: Simon Pilgrim (RKSimon)

<details>
X86 uses ISD::isBuildVectorAllZeros to peek through bitcasts to match zero vectors in a large number of combines.

Ideally we'd use SDPatternMatch to match these combines and use m_Zero() instead, but regrettably this fails to match the zero vectors through bitcasts,

https://github.com/llvm/llvm-project/commit/84397c61f44e62231d1876a745a0c1f74ea8a5b8 shows an example of the regression

If we convert m_Zero() to something closer to m_AllOnes / AllOnes_match we might be able to make this work.
</details>
Hi, I'd like to work on this issue. Could the issue be assigned to me? Thanks!
Good luck! Please keep this ticket updated with your progress so nobody thinks it has been abandoned.
@average-avancha Any progress?

Hi @RKSimon, sorry for the delay but I managed to put together a fix that should allow m_Zero to peek through bitcasts. I'm still testing the solution locally but I think it should work.

Here's my fix on a fork of the repo: https://github.com/average-avancha/llvm-project/pull/1

I can move forward with an actual PR once I'm done locally testing.
I'd appreciate any feedback, thanks!
@average-avancha The patch looks like it's just for IR PatternMatch, have you made any progress on the DAG SDPatternMatch equivalent?
Not at the moment, seems like my effort was misguided. I'll work through the DAG SDPatternMatch section. Sorry about the confusion.
@average-avancha reverse-ping
@RKSimon if @average-avancha isn???t actively working on this, I???d like to claim this issue
ping @average-avancha
I've raised #146871 as there are issues with inconsistent tolerance of undef elements in m_One/m_Zero/m_AllOnes that need addressing as well.
Hi @RKSimon, feel free to reassign this task. I haven't been able to find the time to wrap this up. Sorry for the inconvenience, thanks!
@RKSimon thanks for the heads up. could you assign me to both please? I???ll handle each in a separate PR

issueDTO.title: [FEATURE] <Social Sharing Buttons on Blogs>
issueDTO.description:
### Why do we need this improvement?

Currently, the website lacks a mechanism for users to easily share blog posts on social media platforms. This limits the reach and visibility of the content, making it harder for readers to promote the blogs organically to a broader audience.

### How will this change help?

This change will ease the sharing of blog amongst social platforms.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### How could it be implemented/designed?

Add social sharing buttons to each blog post. These buttons should allow users to share the post on popular platforms such as:

    Twitter
    LinkedIn

Each button should generate a pre-filled sharing link, including the blog post title, URL, and possibly hashtags. For example:

```Twitter: https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?text=Check+out+this+blog!&url=https://www.asyncapi.com/blog/2024-annual-summary#social-media```

The buttons should be visually appealing, lightweight, and non-intrusive. They can be displayed at the top or bottom of each blog post.

### 🚧 Breaking changes

Yes

### 👀 Have you checked for similar open issues?

- [x] I checked and didn't find a similar issue

### 🏢 Have you read the Contributing Guidelines?

- [x] I have read the [Contributing Guidelines](https://github.com/asyncapi/.github/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md)

### Are you willing to work on this issue?

Yes I am willing to submit a PR!

issueDTO.title: Support automatically opening with com.epicgames.launcher://store links
issueDTO.description:
### Problem description

Hey :wave: 

Epic is famous for giving free games every now and then, and I have a Discord bot that alerts me whenever there's a new one available, including a link to the game in question, which on windows opens the epic client on the page of the game.

E.g.: Currently the free game is https://store.epicgames.com/p/melvor-idle-b6a9b3, and its link to open on the epic client is com.epicgames.launcher://store/p/melvor-idle-b6a9b3, so the `melvor-idle-b6a9b3` is the important part here, which indicates the game to go to.

On linux with the heroic games launcher, it just opens firefox `com.epicgames.launcher://store/p/melvor-idle-b6a9b3`, but obviously firefox doesn't know what to do with it. 

### Feature description

Would it be possible to have the same behaviour from the epic games client on the heroic client, opening the game on the store page? Would be very handy for those cases :smile: 

### Alternatives

_No response_

### Additional information

This is a duplicate of https://github.com/Heroic-Games-Launcher/HeroicGamesLauncher/issues/918, which unfortunately was closed by the author
comments: I've run into this too. Please support opening links from games in Firefox too.

The author is on CachyOS (arch-linux on wayland) with Hyprland as the DE, but believes the issue is platform-agnostic. The issue is still open and the author is willing to let someone take a look into it. There are some comments asking for clarification on the codebase and its ability to claim games from the Epic Games Store.

issueDTO.title: Tenor and alt clef swapped
issueDTO.description:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Current Behavior

I believe that the tenor clef and alto clefs are swapped in alphaTex. Setting the clef to tenor gives you an alto clef, and setting the clef to alto gives you a tenor clef.

### Expected Behavior

`\clef Tenor` should show a tenor clef, and `\clef Alto` should give an alto clef

### Steps To Reproduce

Inputting the alphaTex `\clef Alto` outputs a tenor clef

### Link to jsFiddle, CodePen, Project

_No response_

### Version and Environment

```bash
Visible in both https://alphatab.net/docs/playground/ and android version 1.3.0. Indicated on https://alphatab.net/docs/alphatex/bar-metadata#clef
```

### Platform

Web

### Anything else?

_No response_

issueDTO.title: No capital letter in the dropdown menu for permissions
issueDTO.description:
### What happened?

The items in the dropdowns menus for selecting the permissions don't have capital letter.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/00cc41cf-a1ed-4a51-986c-68007b54cfa2)

This is the same in french and english languages.



### What did you expect to happen?

I expect to see the items with capital letters.

### How can we reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)?

1. Go to Map viewer
2. Try to edit infra permissions

### On which environments the bug occurs?

Recette (SNCF)

### On which browser the bug occurs?

Firefox

### OSRD version (top right corner `Account` button > `Informations`)

100faa4

issueDTO.title: Failure in compile

<!--

Thanks for opening an issue! To help the Numba team handle your information
efficiently, please first ensure that there is no other issue present that
already describes the issue you have
(search at https://github.com/numba/numba/issues?&q=is%3Aissue).

-->

## Reporting a bug

<!--

Before submitting a bug report please ensure that you can check off these boxes:

-->

- [x] I have tried using the latest released version of Numba (most recent is
  visible in the release notes
  (https://numba.readthedocs.io/en/stable/release-notes-overview.html).
- [x] I have included a self contained code sample to reproduce the problem.
  i.e. it's possible to run as 'python bug.py'.

<!--

Please include details of the bug here, including, if applicable, what you
expected to happen!

-->

```python
@njit
def _nan_maximum_impl(args):
    result = np.empty(args[0].shape, dtype=args[0].dtype)
    l = len(args)
    for idx, max_value in np.ndenumerate(args[0]):
        for k in range(1, l):
            this_value = args[k][idx]
            if this_value > max_value or np.isnan(max_value):
                max_value = this_value
        result[idx] = max_value
    return result
```
```python
_nan_maximum_impl((np.array(1.0), ))
```

--> 664     ty = values[0].type
    665 ary = ir.ArrayType(ty, n)(ir.Undefined)
    666 for i, v in enumerate(values):

IndexError: list index out of range


```
comments:
This seems to be a case of lack of default value, it looks like the logic at:

https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/0c633b896526b039171c0f800df70320e1c61a53/numba/np/arrayobj.py#L3886

This was built with the intent to make an array of indices but always assumed that the indices would always be present. However in this case they aren't. And `pack_array` clearly states that:

https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/0c633b896526b039171c0f800df70320e1c61a53/numba/core/cgutils.py#L659-L663

So therefore the fix out to be something like:

```
diff --git a/numba/np/arrayobj.py b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
index ccb61b670..5fa670a86 100644
--- a/numba/np/arrayobj.py
+++ b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
@@ -3883,7 +3883,7 @@ def _make_flattening_iter_cls(flatiterty, kind):
                                                                      indices,
                                                                      dim))
                                    for dim in range(ndim)]
-                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals)
+                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals, ty=context.get_data_type(types.intp))
                         result.yield_(
                             cgutils.make_anonymous_struct(builder,
                                                           [idxtuple, value]))
```

Since array indices are always of type `intp`.

summary.main: Failure in compile due to lack of default value in `pack_array` function
summary.validationOrRequirement:
The fix is to provide a default value for the indices, like this: 

diff --git a/numba/np/arrayobj.py b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
index ccb61b670..5fa670a86 100644
--- a/numba/np/arrayobj.py
+++ b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
@@ -3883,7 +3883,7 @@ def _make_flattening_iter_cls(flatiterty, kind):
                                             indices,
                                             dim))
                                    for dim in range(ndim)]
-                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals)
+                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals, ty=context.get_data_type(types.intp))
                         result.yield_(
                             cgutils.make_anonymous_struct(builder,
                                                           [idxtuple, value])
summary.attemptedFixes:
The fix is to provide a default value for the indices, like this: 

diff --git a/numba/np/arrayobj.py b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
index ccb61b670..5fa670a86 100644
--- a/numba/np/arrayobj.py
+++ b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
@@ -3883,7 +3883,7 @@ def _make_flattening_iter_cls(flatiterty, kind):
                                             indices,
                                             dim))
                                    for dim in range(ndim)]
-                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals)
+                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals, ty=context.get_data_type(types.intp))
                         result.yield_(
                             cgutils.make_anonymous_struct(builder,
                                                           [idxtuple, value])
summary.otherNotes:
The issue seems to be a case of lack of default value, specifically in the `pack_array` function. The logic at https://github.com/numba/numba/blob/0c633b896526b039171c0f800df70320e1c61a53/numba/np/arrayobj.py#L3886 assumes that the indices will always be present, but in this case they aren't. The fix is to provide a default value for the indices, like this: 

diff --git a/numba/np/arrayobj.py b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
index ccb61b670..5fa670a86 100644
--- a/numba/np/arrayobj.py
+++ b/numba/np/arrayobj.py
@@ -3883,7 +3883,7 @@ def _make_flattening_iter_cls(flatiterty, kind):
                                             indices,
                                             dim))
                                    for dim in range(ndim)]
-                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals)
+                        idxtuple = cgutils.pack_array(builder, idxvals, ty=context.get_data_type(types.intp))
                         result.yield_(
                             cgutils.make_anonymous_struct(builder,
                                                           [idxtuple, value])

issueDTO.title: Track and Manage Puzzle History
issueDTO.description:
A self-contained PuzzleVersioningModule for storing and managing version history of puzzles. This allows admins to view all past edits, track changes over time, and retrieve the most recent version when needed. Useful for auditing and improving content reliability over time.

**Tasks:**

* [ ] Create `PuzzleVersion` entity to store versioned puzzle data (title, content, timestamp, etc.)
* [ ] Implement logic to fetch and return the latest version of any given puzzle
* [ ] Build an admin-only endpoint or view that lists all versions of a puzzle chronologically

issueDTO.title: Verify signature locally
issueDTO.description:
## Description 📹

**Currently, verifying signatures on Starknet via `is_valid_signature` fails if the account is not deployed. This leads to the error: "your wallet is not yet initialized, please make a transaction (sending ETH to yourself works) to initialize it." To support undeployed accounts, we propose directly verifying the signature using the public key (account address), bypassing the need to interact with the account's contract.**

## Proposed Actions 🛠???

Here???s a checklist of actions to follow for resolving this issue:

1. **Fork and Create Branch**:  
   Fork the repository and create a new branch using the issue number:
   
```bash
   git checkout -b fix-[issue-number]
```

2. **Implement Changes**:  
- [ ] Create a utility function to verify Starknet signatures using public keys directly.
- [ ] Integrate this function as a fallback when account is not yet deployed.
- [ ] Detect if an account is deployed or not before calling `is_valid_signature`.
- [ ] Add error handling and logging for both methods of verification.
- [ ] Write unit tests for both deployed and undeployed account scenarios.

Example snippet for direct signature verification:
```python
def verify_signature(pubkey, message_hash, signature):
    # Apply Starknet signature verification logic using elliptic curve math
    return starknet_ec_verify(pubkey, message_hash, signature)
```

3. **Run Tests and Commit Changes**:  
   Make sure your changes don't break existing functionality and commit with a clear message:
   
```bash
   git commit -m "Fix: Allow signature verification for undeployed Starknet accounts"
```

## Required 📋

To keep our workflow smooth, please make sure you follow these guidelines:

- **Assignment**: Don't create a pull request if you weren???t assigned to this issue.
- **Timeframe**: Complete the task within **3 business days**.
- **Closing the Issue**: In your PR description, close the issue by writing Close #[issue_id].
- **Review Process**:
  - Once you've submitted your PR, change the label to **"ready for review"**.
  - If changes are requested, address them and then update the label back to **"ready for review"** once done.
- **Testing**: Test your PR locally before pushing, and verify that tests and build are working after pushing.

Thank you for your contribution 🙏

?????? WARNING: Failure to follow the requirements above may result in being added to the OnlyDust blacklist, affecting your ability to receive future rewards.

issueDTO.title: Support a unique interface to the logger crate
issueDTO.description:
Currently the format for `defmt` and `log` and different. It would be much more convenient to have a unique syntax for a common (and restricted) subset of those, typically to print common types like integers, strings, and bytes.

The idea would be to change the logger crate to be a proc-macro crate, and do the format conversion logic at compile-time. The goal is that such logic: https://github.com/google/wasefire/blob/ac32ec709398c325c0d0293e84f85345123e3041/crates/protocol-usb/src/device.rs#L91-L94
would be a single line:
```rust
Some(result) => log::debug!("Reading {:02x?}", result),
```

See https://github.com/knurling-rs/defmt/issues/149 for a similar issue in the `defmt` repository.

Once fixed, we should re-enable the `clippy.uninlined_format_args` lint.

issueDTO.title: Support datamodel validations
issueDTO.description:
As user, one can run

    biber --validate_datamodel xyz.bib

Then, the log is filled with entries such as

    WARN - Datamodel: report entry 'Iron2009' (oliver-kopp.bib): Missing mandatory field 'type'

A pattern for this needs to be added to

    org.jabref.logic.biblog.BibtexLogParser

One can develop test driven, to first add a test to

    org.jabref.logic.biblog.BibtexLogParserTest

## Steps

1. Create a new `@ParameterizedTest` at `BibtexLogParserTest` for error strings and expected `BibWarning`. I assume `@MethodSource` will be needed. Add the above test string and result
2. Adapt `BibtexLogParser`

No need to create a new `.blg` file for testing; this is too much effort.
